Review_body: Out of all the movies of "Friday the 13th", "Jason X" is the lowest of the low. It has some good parts that I like, but from the rest of it. It just went downhill fast! An android Kay-Em 14(Lisa Ryder) was a perfect foe for Jason. As supernatural as he is, Jason(Kane Hodder) is the ultimate killer. Now that he's in the future, he's no longer a threat to Camp Crystal Lake, otherwise it was foolish to revive him in the future. Or is it? The silliest thing I saw in this movie was the CyberJason, OH PLEASE! That really takes the cake. Man I thought Part 8 was bad enough, I was wrong, this movie was twice as silly as part 8. However, the upgrade version of Jason seems rather cool in a maniacal way. At least it showed in his eyes. If they glowed, this movie would have been much better. This movie I'll have to pass on the collection list. The upgrade didn't do me any justice, Jason should just stayed dead. 1 out of 5 stars.

Jason Ten (2001) takes place in an unspecified time period. Jason Ten and a female scientist (the very hot Lexa Doig) are frozen in time and are put into an inadvertent suspended animation (Jason V was put in "special custody" by the United States Government, they wanted to study is inhuman healing power so they could create a army of super soldiers). A team of salvages were snooping around a "dead" Earth searching for valuable relics. The crew picks up Lexa and Jason. The crew doesn't know what to do with Jason. Insteadof keeping him on ice. He's reanimated. After putting in some work, Jason is trapped and thrown into a room that is used to accelerate medical conditions. When he emerges, he becomes uber Jason and rips apart the spaceship looking for people to kill. The shocked crew tries everything to stop him. But nothing seems to work. In a desperate move, the destroy the ship. Lexa and the surviving crew members flee to safety whilst one crew member sacrifices himself (in a funny homage to DARK STAR) to eradicate Jason once and for all. Does it work? That's for you to decide.An entertaining entry in the Jason Vorhees Saga. this film is also known as Part Ten. Since this movie takes place in "The Future", we don't know what time period this film takes place in. Let's just say it's WAY after Jason versus Freddy. Not a classic film, take it for what it's worth.Recommended for Jason fans.

I saw Jason X when it came out at the cinema plus a few times on DVD, I have to say that it improves with each viewing. My son has become interested in horror movies, especially Friday the 13th, and this was the perfect introduction. It's a fun movie with some great kills, one of the best sequels post part 4.

This is no doubt the most unique setting Jason has appeared in the big screen. He's been put in a suspended animation and wakes up 450 years in the future.Jason is trapped in a cryostasis until a scientific scout ship consisting of school students and a teacher finds him, and not knowing his immortal nature, bring him back to life within the space ship. The unsuspecting (in the beginning) occupants of the space ship gets hacked and maimed in the usual way you'd expect from Friday the 13th movie, but this one is bit more imaginative because there are more props of the future that can be used to add gory ways people get snuffed by our antihero.For a relatively low budget movie, the special effects are surprisingly good. The actors are all good looking which adds to the quality of the story.Out of all the Friday the 13th movie (so far), this one is my favorite for the action and the visuals this movie has to offer. This was good entertainment, and although it's not for everyone, it appeals to both horror movie, and sci-fi movie affectionados. It's high quality entertainment looking from both genre, and is recommended for viewing.

Review title: I'd say this is better than Jason Goes to Hell, but still nothing special overall
Review_body: Jason X (2001) is the next Friday the 13th film I watched from my personal collection. The storyline is very "alien" like where a ship in space comes across an old spacecraft with Jason cryogenically frozen inside. Of course Jason receives an electric current that sparks him back to life and the killing spree begins. This movie is directed by James Issac (Pig Hunt) and stars David Cronenberg (yes, the director), Peter Mensah (300 and Spartacus), Lexa Doig (Andromeda) and Markus Parilo (Fargo). The storyline for this isn't that great and reminded me of a made for television film in terms of the special effects, especially the outer space scenes. I did like the virtual reality game components, and the old hockey mask in space scenes and references, but there isn't much memorable here outside space being the primary setting. Well, Jason did have the scene where he dry iced her face and smashed her head on the sink...that was cool. Overall, I'd say this is better than Jason Goes to Hell, but still nothing special overall. I'd score this a 4.5/10.

The plot Finally captured in the year 2008, Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder) is held inside a government research facility whose scientists try to answer the question that keeps eluding them - why one of the most infamous mass murderers in history cannot die. Once Rowan (Lexa Doig), leader of the research project, prepares the specimen for cryogenic suspension, a greedy scientist goes over her head and comes to remove Jason, only to have the mad slasher break free and slaughter him and his entire entourage. Tricking Jason into following her, Rowan eludes him into entering the cryogenic freezer and begins the process, but a breach in the system causes her to freeze with him. The government tries to deny any evidence of the project, and nearly four centuries pass, during which the Earth gradually becomes less and less habitable and humans have relocated to a planet in another star system that they've named Earth II. A team of young students descends onto the ruined Earth, where they find the frozen bodies of Jason and Rowan in the forgotten research facility and take back on board their ship with them. Rowan is thawed and revived, but the team mistakes Jason to be dead, having no idea of his abilities or motives. Before long, Jason awakens to the sound of young people having premarital sex once again, and the carnage erupts once again as the ship proceeds to Earth II. The remaining survivors fight for their lives as the centuries-old mad slasher proves that he is just as evil and just as indestructible during their time as he was centuries before.I have seem this movie a few times now, I really liked It the first time saw but every time I see it always find something new i don't like about this movie.The last time we saw Jason he was going to hell and then the next thing we see him being chained up somewhere, I need to ask this How the hell did he get out of Hell ?.I saw this again last night, for some reason I find it really boring and it was hard for me to try stay awake.Jason going to space was not a good idea at all and Jason getting upgrade was such a really bad idea. i hated that turned him into some robot. he was not the Jason we all knew or have been scared of before.The acting wasn't half that bad and there were only one or two good deaths scenes this movie.i going give this movie 4 out 10

Review title: Boldly going where every horror monster has gone before
Review_body: Yes, there comes a time in a horror movie monsters life where they decide to send him into space. The first was "Critters IV: They're invading our space." That one almost made sense, since the critters came from space to start with. And you get to see Angela Basset naked. Or her body double, anyway. Then you had Hellraiser IV: Bloodline, which ended with trapping Pinhead in a dimension where he could only phone it in for direct to DVD sequels. That was followed by "Leprechaun in Space", a movie where I think halfway through, they decided, "Let's make this a farce, no one is taking this seriously, why should we?" The idea is you put the monster in space, and watch him reenact the alien movies.Well, sadly, this was the end they intended to put poor Jason to. They had him get cryogenically frozen and then resurrected on a spaceship, along with Lexa Doig of Andromeda fame. (In a role reversal,Andromeda co-star Lisa Ryder plays an android, and a better one than Doig played on the series. Probably didn't do the casting right.) Of course, Jason comes back from the dead, and starts picking off horny undergrads and space marines. He is apparently killed (right, like that hasn't happened before) but resurrected with the help of nanobots into "Super-Jason".And why would a science ship have giant drill bits sticking straight up to impale star marines on? It boggles the mind.

Review title: Bad Horror Meets Bad Sci-Fi... Results are Bad
Review_body: Easily the fifth or sixth time Friday the 13th has jumped the shark, this time pulling a double corkscrew backflip along the way. Following in the hallowed footsteps of Leprechaun 4, Hellraiser: Bloodline and Critters 4, this installment finds Jason cryogenically frozen for four hundred years and defrosted aboard a lightly-staffed spacecraft. No explanation is offered for his abrupt return from the depths of the nether, where he was unceremoniously dumped at the end of Jason Goes to Hell, though I'm not sure that really would've made a difference. This is a willfully stupid playground for half-baked science fiction ideas, terrible wardrobe choices and budget special effects; a cut-rate production that would feel right at home on the Sci-Fi Channel at 3am. Predictable to the end, it touches all the bases with gratuitous nudity, shallow characters, mysterious returns from certain doom and a truckload of dismemberments / decapitations / deaths. The only thing we're missing is the trademarked screeching cat fake-out, presumably because no self-respecting animal would be seen in such a production. Apart from one fleeting moment of self-deprecating parody near the end - which is totally out of place, but admittedly had me howling - there's no reason for this to exist. It's the kind of thing that would've thrived on the bootleg circuit, akin to Roger Corman's unreleased Fantastic Four, but by actually sending it to theaters, New Line took the wind out of those sails. The best thing I can say here is, hey, at least it's better than the last one.

Jason X is lots of fun & is basically a silly fun B movie Jason film & it's Awesome!!! Jason killing in space in the future IT'S pure crazy late night fun nothing else to say but a fun slasher thrill ride not brilliant but good.

Review title: Another Underrated film people over judge! Decent scifi horror!! Long live JASON!!
Review_body: People just dont get how hard it is to keep making a character work in sequels let alone 10 fricking movies!! This was a creative way to bring jason back and to bring him into the scifi genre. The fight between him and the up graded woman was exceptional! This film is Underrated and underappreciated. I'll watch this once a year along with my massive horror collection. Its actually a 7 but gave it a 9 because of the morons who gave it a score under a 5. On a final note the kills were extremely entertaining in this film.

"Jason X" is the tenth installment in the "Friday the 13th" series. This time, it's 25th century and earth is no longer an inhabitable place for the human race. So, a group of people on a spaceship receive two cryogenically frozen bodies. After unthawing the frozen beings, one of them turns out to be the legendary killer Jason Voorhees. And of course, unfreezing him has brought old Jason back to life. After killing off a whole investigation crew, Jason begins a rampage among the giant spacecraft, killing off anyone and everyone who even comes close to crossing his deadly path.While this movie is fairly enjoyable, the entire idea of "Jason in space" doesn't sit well with me. Why bring one of cinema's most legendary murderers into outer space, the idea is a bit ridiculous if you ask me. Despite this major flaw, "Jason X" is a pretty fun little horror movie. The story - while it is just a little unbelievable - works on most levels. The whole space-age atmosphere to the film was interesting, so any sci-fi fans can relate a little (unfortuantely I'm not one of them). The cast was mostly a bunch of no-name actors, but they all give fairly good performances, keeping in mind this is a Friday the 13th sequel (and the tenth one, might I add). There was one really well-thought up killing in the film that I thought was extremely unique and clever. I won't say anything to give it away, but I'm sure that you'll know what it is when you see it, I thought it was pretty cool.Overall, "Jason X" is a campy horror movie. While the special effects and acting are decent, the whole premise of the movie is pretty silly. If you don't take the film too seriously, you may find it to be enjoyable. This is perfect for any "Friday the 13th" fan who may also be fond of the sci-fi genre, but for all others it may be kind of dumb. Nonethless, it's brainless fun. 5/10.

Review title: Not as bad as some might say
Review_body: Jason X truly isn't as bad as some might want to say. I mean don't get me wrong it's a no cinema masterpiece, but it is entertaining and some parts especially in the fighting/action sequence but it is entertaining in some parts, specially in the fighting/action sequences. I really enjoyed the visual effects and I thought that the fighting scenes were well done. I didn't know whether the CGI digital effects would work or whether they would fall flat, but I can happily report that the CGI actually worked well, especially for 2002. Lexa Doig is good here, and I was surprisingly impressed by her performance. Now the professor in this movie was really annoying and I actually just hated him, like seriously his character was just crap. Kay Em was an awesome character and I enjoyed her presence. Well Jason Voorhees definitely put up a pretty damn good fight, and that is part of what made the movie entertaining. Yes, there were some lines of dialogue that were just pretty stupid and I wish I had not been there, lifelike don't rip my pants, I don't know if they were trying to add comedic relief, but if they were then it just didn't work. Ya know I actually thought I was going to absolutely hate this movie but I just couldn't. Parts of it were just too entertaining to hate. I also liked the intro, I loved the flaming credits rolling in, and truth be told I liked how Lexa Doig opened the movie with that beginning chase scene years in the past. 7/10 for Jason X.

Review title: This Sequel is Fun for the Fans and Something a little new for once.
Review_body: In the year 2009-Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder) is still breathing, still indestructible and still the essence of evil. When a hard working female scientist (Lexa Doig) tries different ways to destroy him but he keeps coming back alive. When the lead scientist trapped Jason to be frozen but she ended being frozen with the undead murderer. 446 years later, when a group of young students on a routine training mission come to discover, when they accidentally discover two frozen bodies and learning that one of them is the legendary killer of Crystal Lake but little what they know, when Jason is defrost. He comes back to life but his new environment and when technology has changed, he goes on a killing rampage but this time on a moving space ship! Directed by James Issac (The Horror Show, a.k.a.-House 3) brings an lively, sometimes funny sequel to the seemingly never-ending series to the Friday the 13th films. Director:Issac and first-time screenwriter:Todd Farmer (He also has a small role in this). The writer added some clever and exciting moments with an delightful fun in the last half hour. Although knowing that the plot is silly and wondering how did Jason come back to life after Jason Goes to Hell. Although fans would like to think of it, it happened after Freddy Vs Jason. Still, the film is surprisingly entertaining with clever visual effects (Some of the CGI effects are quite lame, which some of it is unintentionally hilarious) and Harry Manfredini's music score isn't bad, either. Jason X is actually better than some of the Friday the 13th sequels and it's also less violent or bloody than most.DVD has an great anamorphic Widescreen (1.85:1) transfer with an strong-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound (Also in DTS). DVD has an fine commentary track by the director, writer and producer:Noel Cunningham. DVD has an entertaining 30 minutes documentary on the history of the Friday the 13th films. DVD also has an 17 minutes behind the scenes featurette, trailer and more. Executive Produced by Sean S. Cunningham (Who directed the original-Friday the 13th) and director:Issac. Watch for Canadian filmmaker:David Cronenberg and actor:Robert S. Silverman in cameos. True Fans of the Series will love this one. Filmed in 2000. (*** ½/*****).

The last of the original "Friday the 13th" series, and the least. Jason is put into deep freeze sometime in the 21st Century, but gets thawed out as a scientific curiosity during a student field trip aboard a spacecraft in the far off future. Kane Hodder returns for his fourth and final go-round as Jason and is his usual dependable self. The idea of featuring "Jase In Space" sounds absurd at first, but it works within the movie because despite his surroundings, Jason himself still remains rooted in his mindless and indiscriminating killing persona; this time he just happens to be a victim trapped in a world beyond his understanding or control. However, what really weakens this one substantially for me is that there are too many dumb jokes, and these teenagers who are supposed to be from the year 2455 still look, act, and spout dopey colloquialisms exactly like today's dopey teenagers. The writing and dialogue in particular could have been much better. A few highlights include the "liquid nitrogen face death" (one of the top kills in Jason history) and the humorous "virtual reality sequences". At least the ending devised an interesting way to eliminate Jason once and for all. ** out of ****

Surprise! "Jason In Space" is a horror-comedy!I tend to greatly enjoy movies that know exactly what they are and make no apologies for it. I regard 'Jason X' much the same way I do 'Godzilla: Final Wars' or 'Escape from L.A.'-the writers clearly wink or nod at the audience as though to say, "Yep. This is what we're doing." If that's not the sort of film for you, I understand, but you're missing out on a fun, wild ride as everything possible is thrown in just for kicks.Everything is very deliberately over the top: effects, sets, costumes, make-up, to say nothing of the plot. Dialogue is at turns boneheaded and drily witty, complementing deaths that are alternately brutal and cartoonish (or why not both?). The actors here are all having a great time, putting in the most convincing performances they can in a film that does not require it. It's hard not to imagine that every day on set was more fun than work.While the whole affair is played very seriously, there's no fright to be had here, only thrills and laughs. I can appreciate that such a sudden turn for a reputed slasher franchise may be off-putting. Yet it's not terribly often that a horror film (albeit a horror-comedy) can upend expectations like this, and moreover, 'Jason X' crafts a uniquely different film that manages to arguably be more true to itself than its predecessors could muster.It's hard to miss the generally poor reception for this movie. Usually I'd remark that would-be viewers clearly weren't in the target audience, but that's not true: it's more that the target audience didn't know they were targets of a joke.Drop your expectations for what you think 'Friday the 13th' should be. Sit back, relax, and enjoy what is one of the most fun movies I think I've ever seen.

Review title: At least Jason X tried to do something different
Review_body: I must confess that I am not really a fan of the Friday The 13th series. As a teenager, I saw most of the sequels on HBO and could tell little difference between them. So taking a cryogenically frozen Jason and putting him 400 years in the future in outer space is not the worst idea out there. I actually thought that could be a good premise to a tired franchise. Jason X has a lot of problems and is a mixed bag that ultimately is guilty pleasure viewing. I do enjoy this for a laugh, but it could have been legitimately good if it was taken more seriously. The writing, dialogue and acting is really bad, with a mostly clueless young cast that could have been on Dawson's Creek or something. It does what most science fiction does and rips off Star Trek. The tone is really silly and tongue in cheek. However, Kane Hodder is as great here as our hero Jason and he is as menacing as ever. The money from the film obviously went into special f/x and cinematography. Jason X really looks great, but with a flimsy plot and goofy acting the film falls flat on it's face. But if that was tightened up, Jason X could have gone the distance. That having been said, I enjoy Jason X and Freddy Vs Jason much better than the other films in the series.

Review title: The film feels like it was made by a horny teenage nerd...but that doesn't mean it isn't fun to watch
Review_body: Silly, juvenile, but admittedly fun- Jason X never really decides whether it wants to be a parody or actually take it seriously, but there is some entertaining moments along the way. First thing first, I don't like this movie, and there are certainly quite a few reasons why. First off, the majority of the acting is pretty horrible, with Lisa Ryder being the only halfway decent actress throughout the whole film. The set looks cheaply made, like a bunch of rejected sets of an early 2000's sci-fi film that was never made. The CGI can be quite obvious at times, although it isn't horrible, despite it sticking out so much. Some of the dialogue is super ridiculous, and in general the film is poorly written with some things clearly showing this film was made in 2001 and not 4 centuries in the future. Despite all that though, this film is surprisingly fun to watch, and is quite possibly one of the most entertaining entries in the franchise as a whole. Its kills can be fun from time to time, its setting and technology somewhat interesting, and its goofy antics are obviously stupid, but quite enjoyable to see play out on screen. In the end, Jason X was not nearly as bad as I thought it may be, although it certainly isn't in any way a good film. Maybe its unneeded, maybe its dumb and childish, but it certainly isn't the worst film ever made, nor the worst in the franchise.My Rating: 4.8/10.

Review title: There is No Where Else to Go!
Review_body: Where else is Jason going to go? He's been to New York City....where else is there? Even though Jason returns to face Freddy, this should be the last we see of Jason. Unless Jason decided to attack martians on Mars, Jason has been there and done that. A nice science fiction / horror movie that fails on all levels, the gore hardly keeps the audience interested in seeing what happens. A typical horror cast that does nothing for the film. The human race has not evolved much since Jason began killing horny teenagers on Crystal Lake. In the future, teenagers are still horny and are vulnerable to psycho's named Jason. One of the worst of the 10, many felt Tom Savini should have directed this one. Instead, we hopefully close the book on Jason after an impressive 21 year run. Jason is due to retire. Thank God!

Wow! Talk about your piece of garbage. I haven't been this entertained in so long, I might have busted my sides. Obviously, this film was made to satirize itself. Or was it?Bad acting, funky lighting and ridiculous dialogue really create quite a quandary: Is it good because it's so bad or is it too good to be considered terrible?I've decided to label this film a piece of brilliant stupidity. Most idiotic films try to hard to make themselves legitimate, but Jason X simply throws all of those thoughts out the window. This may be the best sequel in the series, which isn't saying much, but then again, what does one expect from a film series with 10 remakes of itself. I will say this,it will be a hell of a lot better than Halloween Resurrection.If you've seen the trailer for it, this film takes itselfway too seriously. For crying out loud, how many times can Michael Myers come back in a serious and scary fashion? The producing team for Halloween should take notes from Jason X: you've made far too many sequels up to this point, so you might as well have a little fun with it.I will also say this: David Cronenberg's cameo performance was pretty cool, and Lexa Doig was ravishing.

If you're asking me if this movie is good, my answer is no; not by a long shot. If you're asking me if this movie is entertaining, then my answer is absolutely; it's one of the more entertaining movies I've seen this year. This movie doesn't succeed in being scary, nor does it do anything to advance Jason's overall storyline (I'm pretty sure most people wouldn't consider this cannon), but there are plenty of gory, sometimes hysterical, kills that fill this film's meager runtime.
F

Review title: yes and no about Jason X (and a few BEEPs)
Review_body: so you want to see a BEEPy movie so you can BEEP your date? be sure not to watch Jason X, because it's such a BEEP your date will not want to BEEP you anymore. yes, it's stupid. yes, it's more scifi than horror. yes, sean cunningham is still member of the crew. no this is not exactly another Friday the 13th movie. at least not one like you suspect one to be. yes, Jason has got some new looks, so he doesn't look like Jason anymore. no, it is not a sequel, since Jason goes to Hell ended with Freddy and Jason. but don't be afraid, Freddy and Jason will battle each other in the next Friday the 13th chapter: Freddy vs Jason. just skip this BEEP and watch Freddy and Jason instead. by the way, during that movie, your date will definitely want to BEEP you.

After the abysmal "Jason Goes to Hell," anything seemed better. And why not make a movie so the amount of instalments is an even 10? Luckily, this goes back to same non-serious fun Jason films of previous instalments. And after watching the previous Jason movie, it really elevated Jason X.After being sent to hell in "Jason Goes To Hell," Freddy obviously resurrects him and his body-count in growing. It is the mid 2000s and Jason has been captured and cryogenically frozen. They freeze him because they can't figure out a way to destroy him forever. Only the supernatural can do it! But Jason's brutish strength messes things up and he gets frozen with one of the researchers. Fast forward 450 years. A group of college students are travelling on a spaceship and stumble upon Jason and the girl. Both are thawed and then the movie turns into Alien with Jason as the monster. When we get to see the students and their professor, its pretty silly. Good for laughs. When Jason awakens and tries to destroy all, we actually become invested. When Jason gets upgraded into the most powerful he could ever be, it's pretty kick-ass.In the year 2455, some of the futuristic things we see is pretty cool. And a spaceship is cool to see in general. And add one of cinema's coolest monsters to wreck havoc. The way all this is added up makes the movie totally bad-ass. Sure the acting is dull and its not very smart, but the fights and Uber Jason are all so fun!I gave some earlier instalments thumbs up just because they were fun and they didn't demand to be taken seriously. Jason X is one of those.3/4

The first film came out in 1980 and here I am in 2003 watching the newest Jason film! And to top it off, the next one has been made and it has Freddy in it! About the only positive thing that I can say about this series is that it stopped taking itself seriously a long time ago. This film starts out with Jason hanging in chains and of course he busts out. A female scientist named Rowan (Lexia Doig) locks Jason in a cryogenic chamber and freezes him. But they're is a leak and she gets frozen as well. Now zoom up 400 years and some crew on a space ship find them and take them on board. Let the thawing begin! Most of the actors in this film look no older than 25. And most of them look like models. At one point in the film a very hot female is suppose to be a scientist examining Jasons tissue and she wears a belly shirt. In fact, most of the hot chicks on board wear belly shirts. All the characters in this film act just as dumb and irrational as the characters in the original 1980 film. So much for progress! One of the more appealing characters is a female robot (Hot looking of course) named Kay-EM14 (Lisa Ryder) and she gets horny like everyone else but Ryder seems to be having fun playing it. As far as sequels go you know one of the last resorts is to put the story in outer space. Remember "Highlander II" and the last "Hellraiser" film? Well, they're going to have to resurrect him somehow for his battle with Freddy. For you trivia nuts, David Cronenberg makes a cameo and Cronenberg regular Robert Silverman has one scene as well.

I don't understand how you guys can find this movie predictable and boring. The deaths were such creative, the scenario was very innovator and the acting was good. How can it be the worst thriller ever? The only bad thing for me is that they took too long to finish the movie. They could have avoided some comes and goes about the spacecraft's security which was unnecessary, but the non-clichéd ending made up for this. Am I the only one who didn't find plot holes in here? I mean, it's extremely hard to find a horror movie without lots of them, and this movie surprisingly avoided it.I could notice a criticism to the capitalism system, accusing it of putting money above people. It also reminded me of "The Cube(1996)", even though their criticism was about job's alienation. A good watch for horror fans, and I hope watching good movies like that in future.
Most people think of Jason X as Friday the 13th in space. It is. Made to capitalize on the sci-fi craze of the late 1990s and early 2000s, this film, the tenth in the franchise, sucks.

Review title: "I think he's gone." "Why don't you stick your head out there and find out??"
Review_body: First of all, I don't quite understand the 'hate' for this tenth installment of the Friday/Jason series. It's "Friday the 13th", for crying out loud! ANY change in the direction of the series is welcome at this point. It seems as if the fans have forgotten how 'winded' the Jason series had become - after the absolute dregs of the series in "Jason Goes To Hell", "Jason Takes Manhattan" and "The New Breed", the series' creators were not just beating a dead horse, they were dragging it around the track behind a tractor. "Jason X" at least tries to give the horse a jolt with the defibrillator. In spite of the 2nd rate effects, and general silliness, the 10th film in the series has visual energy and freshness that has been missing for at least a decade. The characters are all stereotypes, but they are GOOD stereotypes in new, snazzy 'futuristic' costumes, and they get to use snazzy new assault rifles and hologram projectors and stuff to fight back. It doesn't work of course, and Jason still kicks everybody's butt, but the change in atmosphere and sets does rescue the film from the tedious dread of previous installments. There is some actual levity and some winking tribute to some of the classic conventions of earlier films (such as when Jason beats one camper to death with another one, but it's OK because they are holograms). And Jason gets a 'new look' in the middle of the film. It doesn't really add that much to the character, but again, at least it is different enough to help you 'see' the character again after decades of over-familiarity. I rented this DVD fully expecting it to suck, but to my surprise, the opening scenes and the way the premise was set up caught my bemused interest, and the SFX of the future were JUST good enough to entertain my eyes. And eventually I ended up enjoying the proceedings quite a bit. Not nearly as much as a 'real' movie, of course, but much more than I ever expected from "Friday the 13th" ever again. I'd say it is the only really watchable entry in the series in several years, and if there are no more after this (and I hope not), "Jason X" is not a bad way for FXIII to end.

Review title: It's a good film to sit down in front of and switch off your brain for a bit.
Review_body: There have been a lot of negative comments about this film, but honestly, what do people expect of a tenth installment? The Jason Vorhees movies continue not because they're good, but because they are a tried and tested formula - blood, mayhem and gore. There's no deep meaning here. It's just more of the same.If you go into this movie expecting anything other than silliness and blood-splattering, you'll hate it. On the other hand if, like me, you expected it to be diabolically bad, then you'll be pleasantly surprised.Of course it's throw-away rubbish, but it knows it's crap, and pokes fun at itself. And for that reason it's a good film to sit down in front of and switch off your brain for a bit and have a laugh.Apart from the original movie I can only recall seeing part of one of the intervening series of films - some nonsense with Jason on a boat. So I can't comment on whether it's better or worse than the others. Even my memory of the original is hazy now. But this episode is not too bad.The best bit is the android girl who gets "reprogrammed" by her creator/would-be-lover into a killing machine. Up to that point she was mildly uninteresting, as all the characters are. After that, I was rooting for her the rest of the film. The others are fairly bland and die in an assortment of ways, some more amusing than others.There's some hokum about how Jason keeps going and why he regenerates etc. but it's just added fluff to the carnage. There's also the obligatory sexual scene, but it's tame and light.Not very good, but for a tenth movie of a franchise, it holds up quite well.

or: Jason X, People 0.After being cryogenically frozen for half a millennium, the unhappiest camper of all time is transported via space station to Earth 2 (the sequel?) and accidentally thawed out. He begins hacking and slashing his way through a group of less obnoxious nitwits on board the space station in deep space.Uneven structure, the film is basically two acts: the first last about 20 minutes, and sets up Jason being frozen and thawed. Then the second act has him slaughtering a commando unit, and various other people on board this space station, for the remainder of the film's run time. Film never really climaxes, it just stops in a way which the filmmakers incorrectly think is clever and humorous.A definite improvement over the previous film, Jason goes to Hell, but there are absolutely no scares. Technically well made, this is mostly a science fiction/ comedy, as the film is set on board a space station and the majority of the dialogue is one-liners. Jason makeup has been toned down considerably: no longer is he a rotting, walking corpse; here, he appears to be just a guy in a hockey mask. But that works for this movie, for some reason. I kind of liked it that way for a change. The characters are fairly dim, as always, but not as repulsive as in a couple other installments of this series. Lexa Doig, Kane Hodder, and Peter Mensah do surprisingly well with their characters and the material, which is the biggest asset for this movie.Filmed in March and April 2000, released in Germany in July 2001, Spain in November 2001, South America in January and February 2002, Stateside and the rest of the world did get it until at least the spring of 2002, giving this film probably the oddest, longest delayed release in the series' history.

The creators of this movie don't seem to quite know what they want to accomplish here. There's a strong sense of parody and a sense of humor in the advertising campaigns, but this doesn't really kick in until about the last third of the movie. Before then it's pretty much bog-standard "generic horror flick" with some minimal nods to the updated science-fiction setting. Once the creators start having a little fun with the s.f. elements, and the KM unit gets upgraded into your typical "leather clad dominatrix/fighter" persona from most video games,  things start to kick in a bit. Not surprisingly, Lisa Ryder as KM is about the only person who seems to be having any fun with her part.  The virtual Crystal Lake is also a good idea, although tossed away way too quickly. The ending is also kinda cute in a circular/self-parody kinda way. Unfortunately, it's pretty boring for the first two-thirds, and the audience I was with didn't laugh once at any of the funny stuff in the early stuff. Overall, not too good and probably should have gone with direct-to-video.

Review title: One of the better sequels to a tired series.
Review_body: I'll be honest to start. I'm not a big fan of the Friday series or Jason. I find the idea of the indestructible boogeyman a stupid one. By the time the 3rd sequel came around (the 3D one), I went to see these for two reasons: Nudity and Killings. When the censors started cutting the gore out - I stopped paying attention at all. Jason X is the best of the later sequels. It has an interesting idea, Jason waking up in the future, and a cast that can actually act and that the audience can actually root for. Jason is as menacing as ever (honestly, I could have used more gore, a lynchpin of the originals), and it's quick and fun. Just grab some popcorn and, as usual, turn off your brain.

Review title: "Jason X"- The one that was so bad, not even a David Cronenberg cameo or a sexy cyborg firing machine guns could make it interesting...
Review_body: Look, I'm gonna be up-front about this....I don't know why "Jason X" gets a free-pass from so many people. And I especially don't understand how so many people actually really enjoy it or find it "entertaining." I really just don't get the appeal of it at all, nor can I really figure out what it hopes to accomplish.It's a film that aspires to be so much more than it is, but it never lives up to even a hint of what it promises. It's a contradictory film from scene to scene. On one hand, it fancies itself a subversive satire along the lines of "Jason Lives", yet it only delivers the occasional jest at its own expense. On the other hand, if often plays the material straight for attempts at honest thrills, yet these are contradictory to its lighter moments. It occasionally gets the idea that it's an effects spectacle on the rare occasion for more complex sequences, but it's hindered by a low budget. Yet it also frequently seems aware of its cheap cost in other scenes.It's like watching someone trying desperately to put together two different jigsaw puzzles after the pieces have become inadvertently mixed together. Nothing fits.We all know the plot... It's "Friday the 13th" in space. Jason gets cryogenically frozen (along with sexy scientist Rowan, portrayed by Lexa Doig) in modern times, only to be awakened on a spaceship 400 years later, so he can hack up stupid, nubile teens... in the future!Blah, blah, blah. He kills a few, gets blown apart by a sexy android chick (Lisa Ryder), gets brought back with magical future medical-technology as a half-robotic "Uber Jason", and chaos ensues. (That was all in the trailer, so there's no spoilers there.) It's a rinse and repeat of almost every previous film, except now Jason gets a hokey new metallic costume and there's a lot of bad CGI and green-screen effects because, you know... the future! And space!To be fair and give credit where it is due, there's a few positive aspects here. Lisa Ryder steals the show as robotic "KM-14" in a delightful little role. There's also some fun to be had with a few high-concept gags like a laugh-out-loud holographic simulation of Crystal Lake in the 80's. And I'd be lying if I said there weren't a few creative kills. (Cryo-freezing someone's face and then smashing it? Yes, please!) There's also a cameo from filmmaking god David Cronenberg, who chews the scenery in a fun-albeit-brief role! (How did they even get him for this movie?! Is he a big Jason fan?)But the film never comes together as I said. I can't help but feel screenwriter Todd Farmer was aiming at something a lot bigger and more bombastic, but kept having to be dialed back by studio-suits and producers over budgetary concerns. A lot of the scenes and plot lines come across as last-minute back-ups that were thrown in in case the studio couldn't afford the intended sequences.The tragedy is that it had a golden opportunity to do so much more. The "Killer in Space" trope is such a widely-known cliché, that putting more effort into subverting and parodying the concept would have given the film a fresher, more unique flavor. It needed to drop its more serious moments and take full advantage of delivering self-aware laughs based around its setting and location. The few times it tries, it works. But it doesn't take enough advantage of this... it's not commenting on the silly "killer in space" trope. It's just another example of it being done poorly, while giving us an occasional fleeting wink and nod.Even beyond the failed potential, there's just a whole lot of nothing going on. The effects budget eats up too much money, so everything else- sets, costume design, etc. look cheap and fake. Director James Isaac seems in over his head, and only delivers a minimum effort in his visuals. Series composer Harry Manfredini- usually a reliable musician in his own right- barely seems to try with a really bad and often artificial-sounding synth soundtrack. And supporting roles are among the series worst, with grating characters being portrayed by dime-a-dozen "pretty face" actors who would be more at home on Hollister billboards than on-screen. (Shelly from Part III and Megan from Part VI still remain the high point of supporting roles even to this day.)So sadly, "Jason X" emerges as one of the weakest films in the series in my opinion. It may think it's something grander than it is, but we as an audience can see that this just isn't the case.It's a 2 out of 10 just for it's few fun moments. But they aren't worth having to slog through 90 minutes to get to.

Review title: I would support and cheer for Jason if he took on the Addams Family!
Review_body: The saddest comment on this tenth installment of a cinematic INSTITUTION is that in ran in Sydney for just 6 working days - that is simply pathetic!!!! As one reviewer so aptly commented, Jason X is to the FRIDAY 13TH franchise what BRIDE OF CHUCKY was to the CHUCKY series! OK...granted - this was no masterpiece but hey, for any serious devotee of the Jason culture - this offers so much! terrific one-liners, a marvellous virtual Camp Crystal Lake sequence and with Kane Hodder behind the mask - the definitive Jason! (His fourth outing I believe!) Jason in space is no dumber than his last re-invention....as an alien parasite in JASON GOES TO HELL: THE FINAL FRIDAY - and ludicrous and misplaced as THAT was...I was entertained!JASON X was originally conceived as a JASON vs FREDDIE slasher epic, but somewhere in the legal logistics they couldn't get their act together and thus Jason found himself alone in a cryogenic chamber and ultimately helming his own little blood-letting space odyssey! If you have any awareness at all, you will get a lot out of this film - don't look at it on the surface...that was never the makers' intent!I was bitterly disappointed to have to watch this tenth outing..more than one year late in its Australian release, in the company of less than 5 people recently! The film had NO advance publicity, no critical coverage and basically no media advertising of any description! Its "failure" was carefully orchestrated. Got news for you people, they've been trying to "kill off Jason" for almost a generation...its gonna take more than your contribution, believe me.  Jason will ALWAYS live!

Review title: Lots of fluff and NOT scary.
Review_body: I saw this movie because my friend kept saying how awesome it should be. Well, this movie combines elements from Star Trek (Next Generation), American Pie and all the other Jason movies.  The fact that Jason's "upgrade" was aggravating.  You see, Jason was only enhanced for about 10 percent of the movie.  For the entire other 90 percent he was like the old Jason.  Also, there were these ANTS that could regenerate wounds and heal. What made me mad was that these ants enhanced Jason but they didn't repair any of Jason's victims.  What's up with THAT?  That infuriated me!  So many plot holes.  Why are their nothing but American Pie hot chicks on this "space ship"?  That was lame.  Even the band girl from American Pie was in this movie.  Her death was the grossest.  She was sucked through a vent due to a hole in the spaceship that made all the air go out into space.  There were other gross killings.  One guy was impaled on a screw (giant).  When one of crew asks what this guys condition is, the reply is "he's screwed". How NOT funny.  There was even an ANDROID that somehow manages to do the MOST damage to Jason.  This ANDROID was kind of like DATA!!  She yearned to "become human."  Can you say, RIP OFF OF STAR TREK!?  Of course, there is the tough black sergeant who resembles the Candyman.  He's all tough and says some really stupid lines.  I hated this movie.  What made it worse was that everybody in the theater was hysterically laughing.  That's BAD MOVIE EDIKIT!  I would suggest seeing this if you want to see a bad movie, other than that, stick to the BEST one.  Friday the 13th part 2!

Review title: Is the 'Jason' franchise beyond a joke?! Apparently not!
Review_body: Thanks to "Scream", we live in an age where post-modern horror is now the 'de-rigeur' thing; and your franchise is nowhere unless you have at least ONE entry that follows such a pattern. (Think "Freddy" & Chucky"... ) So comes 'Jason X'; and it's clear from the start that there's nothing at all here that was meant to be taken seriously. This is an episode definitely NOT above chucking in liberal doses of humour to go along with the required entrails and thus hopefully swell the studio coffers. You know what? I prefer it this way, too! Staunch devotees may find themselves disagreeing with me, but this is a welcome new direction for Mr. Voorhees; and the knowing chuckles combined with lots and lots of blood turn what could have been yet another painful slog into a fun send-up of horror clichés past - and indeed, tired plot-elements in general...I'd rather they go for the funny-bone where the Fridays are concerned; since I can't honestly say I had all that much affection for them in the first place; unlike in the cases of Child's Play and A Nightmare on Elm Street. It's been proved that the former AND the latter are perfectly suited to 'seriousness'; whereas I've ALWAYS struggled to take Jason seriously as anything more than a cheap Michael Myers knockoff, right from the start - so this could be his 'niche'... !!! The movie finds time to use its future setting cleverly; exploiting the possibilities both for elaborate deaths, and indeed, the 'post-modern wit' earlier described... A clever use of virtual-reality in particular to ensnare Jason provides a fun projection of how people might look back on the saga as a whole, in our OWN distant future! The props may have gone a little more 'space-age' (if perhaps, no less 'cheap-looking'... !) but it's nice to see that underneath the new exterior there is still retained a certain element of people lurking behind props in the haunted house, waiting to go "Boo"... ! 'Terror' is quite a simple reflex-mechanism to engender, if you think about it; and most of the old values are happily not lost, even though the surroundings were deemed in need of an 'upgrade'...Judging on "Resurrection", the 'Halloween' series ought to think seriously about the option of gravitating toward INTENTIONAL laughs, too... Yes, this film features pretty amateur surgeons in sheer cutoff tops; but what the heck is wrong with that, when the dominant tone is one of tongue-in-cheek spoofery???! Traversing the comedic route has effectively resuscitated this series more effectively than a bolt of lightning EVER did... If people can't hear you 'scream' in space, they might be able to hear you chortle, at least... ! (Yes, there are SEVERAL references to the 'Alien' franchise in the actual movie, as well!)

I know alot of people love this one. But besides some clever homages and one cool ass death scene with liquid nitrogen it all plays out like an overly mediocre episode of andromeda which makes sense because so many people from the show are responsible for this. The plot is unimportant but basically Jason is frozen and than thawed out in the future aboard a space ship where he wreaks havoc. The FX are okay and the characters are mostly unlikable and annoying aside from the retro leading lady and Kane Hodder of course. It's not a terrible movie I especially enjoyed the 80s sleeping bag scene but I do feel like it's the weakest of the series. The uber Jason design is cool but unnecessary and the fact that they're aware their making a bad movie is i believe its biggest problem. Because instead of avoiding those pitfalls it becomes what it's making fun of.2.5/5

Review title: Jason Goes on a Star Trek!!!
Review_body: (I'm pretending that this takes place after FREDDY VS. JASON) Years after Jason won the battle with Freddy, he is caught by the Government. He is about to be frozen, then some stupid Government people come and want to take Jason away for more research. Jason is finally frozen after Rowan shoots him into cryogenic chamber. Jason stabs her, freezing her as well. 445 years later, Jason and Rowan are found and taken to a spacecraft with some students aboard. Rowan is helped, and Jason wakes himself up. Soon, a bloody massacre happens. The ships soldiers try to stop him, but they can't. Later, an android named Kay-Em 14 is uploaded and kills Jason. Then, Jason is upgraded by the nanotechnology. Jason looks awesome when this happens!!! One of the students tries to distract Jason by using a simulation of Crystal Lake, but Jason soon realizes, it's a fake. It's an awesome horror/sci fi film and an awesome Jason film. If you love Jason and sci fi movies, you'll love JASON X!!!

Review title: Is this the best they could come up with?
Review_body:
Warning: may be some spoilersYou know, back in the day, Jason was actually scary.  He was a true killing machine that could strike fear in those that watched his films and worshipped him in some way.  But as the films and years went on, something strange and unfortunate happened; Jason got incredibly bland and worse than that he became a cheap caricature of himself.  Jason was once the epitome of fear, now he is just an after-thought.  This is a tangential film that only bears the villains name to remind us what once was.  And my advice to Sean Cunningham is to either stop making the Friday films all together or get back to the old formula or what was once remembered as a proud franchise that pioneered the horror craze in the 80's is going to sink under it's own ineptitude.  And this is coming from one of it's biggest fans.  Please, make it better.Can you remember back to the early Friday's?  Can you remember what made watching the films so much fun?  It was the fact that first of all, Jason was scary but moreso he was also very phlegmatic, like Michael Myers was. He didn't take things personally, he just killed without passion.  He was the ultimate killer.  In the first four films, Jason was nothing more than a boy who had grown up to kill with an insatiable need for blood and corpses. Now the franchise has gone off on it's own little tangent and subjected Jason to a ridiculous folklore that just doesn't fit with who he was.  Part 9 dropped the ball by inundating us with that stupid "special knife" story and a sister angle when all of us know damn well that he was an only child. Face it, unless you are George Lucas, you cannot introduce family members late into a story and get away with it.  So Jason goes to Hell with Freddy bringing him there but now he in space and he decides that he has to kill again and again and again but with no real passion.  There is no stalking in this one, there is no desperation.  All we have is Jason rounding a few corners and killing the next person that no one cares about.  At least in the earlier ones we knew a little bit about who he was killing.  Think Tommy Jarvis, think Shelly, think of Chris, think of Ginny and Paul and Rick and so on.  There was at least a bit of character development to the people that Jason was slaughtering.  There was also a legend and most of all there was atmosphere.  And correct me if I am way off base here, but didn't James Cameron already take this premise and do it much better in 1986 with guys like Bill Paxton, Lance Henrikson and Michael Biehn?There was one very well done scene in Jason X and that was when he is in VR Crystal Lake.  Someone else commented that all of a sudden the film became interesting again when he was there.  You could hear the music, you could see the cabins and the lake and suddenly that comforting feeling of Jason at Crystal Lake was omnipresent again.  Jason X doesn't have the slightest idea of what it was that made the franchise so successful in the first place. 
This is one of the lousiest films I have seen and I was sure that nothing could top part nine and eight as the worst Friday's but this one does.0 out of 10

Review title: For serious Friday fans only(minor spoilers)
Review_body: The fan in me loved Jason X, but the critic in me hated. First let's start with the fna part. The film has nudity, great one liners and good death scenes that one would expect from a Friday film. Now the critic in me knows that h can pull a better film out of his a*s. The movie is horribly edited, the dialouge is horrible and the acting is very tepid. There's also no back story what so ever. See this one only if you're a serious Friday fan.

Review title: Not as bad as people say it is...
Review_body: When a film series hits ten sequels, you know that the writing staff are just trying to hold onto any kind of meal ticket they possibly can, sure that nothing else they put together will bring home the bacon. After all, who can honestly look me in the eye and say that the tenth James Bond film (or any episode featuring Roger Moore) was anything other than an expensive stream of fire-lighters?It seems there are two schools of thought about Jason X as a result. There are the hardcore fans who seem to think that using the same basic plot over and over and over is a good thing despite the fact that this episode outgrossed its three most immediate predecessors put together. Then there are the people who have watched more than two dozen films in their lifetime, and are ready to recognise that sometimes a little variety is a good thing.Jason X distinguishes itself from the previous eight rehashes by adding a very basic, superficial sci-fi setting. This is the first good move, as one critic I normally violently disagree with has described the other eight films as "the ultimate in recycling - so much so that you forget which episode you are watching after a while". At least there is little chance of mistaking Jason X for episodes one through nine. There is also the element of digital photography. I would have loved to have seen this film theatrically, especially after the grainy, out of focus crap that George Lucas proclaimed as the future with his digital Star Wars. It would have been nice to see if digital photography truly is capable of delivering what its proponents claim. If the DVD-Video of Jason X is anything to go by, then George Lucas should be informed that he is doing more to hurt the digital revolution than help it.Anyway, I am not going to comment on the plot, since it has been done to death, and it appears that the American Butcher's Association has once again failed to recognise that adults watch films, too. The DVD-Video sold in Australia runs almost as long as the IMDB-quoted theatrical running time, which means that at least three and a half minutes of footage that was deleted from the USA theatrical exhibition is present on Australian home videos. About the only complaint that I have here is the Kay-Em droid, who really does more to annoy the audience and ruin the experience than add to anyone's enjoyment. Kane Hodder is in great form as the hockey-masked killer, however. Unlike the majority of people who have played Jason in the past, Hodder really looks the part of a demented woodsman who has grown up totally cut off from civilisation. Anyone who has any doubts about that should take a good look at some of the frontal shots of Uber-Jason. That guy really must have eaten his Wheaties as a boy. Such a pity that the MPAA butchered his first two appearances as Jason beyond recognition (a fact that is hilariously referenced in the illusion-campsite scene).In all, if you are into films, and not circular rehashes of the same old tired plot ad nauseum, then Jason X is for you. It's not the most creative thing you'll ever see, and it's not the best horror film on Earth, but the mere fact that they were brave enough to do something different and have a little bit of fun with it elevates the tenth Friday The 13th far above eight of its nine predecessors. I can see why they dumped the FT13 moniker, quite frankly.

*SOME SPOILERS AHEAD*I'm glad James Isaac, the director, decided to return to the B-movie formula after the disappointing "Jason Goes to Hell," which was simply a failed A-movie effort.  Now, the acting, storyline and dialogue are definitely in perfect B-movie tradition, but the directing and production design were quite impressive.  I loved the color schemes and use of the digital camera, which was then transferred onto film.  I loved the digital look of the film, it's almost flawless.  And though the special f/x were obviously generated by computers, they also looked pretty cool.  OK, so we got ourselves another screwy idea of how to bring Jason back to life, but heck...we love Jason so much that we can't stand to see him go. What makes "Jason X" so much fun to watch is that there's no pretentions. This is pure camp and doesn't try to be any more than pure camp, and it simply takes the genre of camp slasher flick and runs with it as far as it can.  This tenth (I'm not quite sure if I can call it the final) chapter contains a lot more humor than the previous sequels.  Most of the sequels did contain a certain degree of humor, but this one takes the cake.  There are many funny scenes and lines of dialogue, including one where one of the female victims is about to die and her last words are "This sucks on so many levels."  Another funny line occurs when the big black guy got stabbed in the ribs by Jason.  He says, "It'll take more than a poke in the ribs to kill me."  After Jason stabs him again, he says, "That'll do."  You can call this movie weird, you can call it insane, but you gotta give it points for originality.  Of course, in great B-movie tradition, all the female characters look like they leaped straight out of the pages of "Playboy" or "Penthouse."  Even the scientist, who gets frozen along with Jason, is hot as hell.  Though most of these chicks don't get naked, at least they run around in tight, skimpy clothing.  As I've said in past reviews, most of the people watching these flicks are guys, so you may as well appeal to the general demographic.  I just wish that gloriously hot blonde chick in the beginning didn't get killed off so early and died of such ugly death--her face frozen and smashed into pieces.  As far as the nudity factor goes, at least I got my wish at the near end of the film, when those two hot babes stripped off their tops. It kinda sucks that there was only brief nudity, but it's definitely a scene worth fast-forwarding to and rewinding over and over again. 
The most entertaining scene in the movie is when the victims are all cornered by Jason and don't know what the hell to do, until the robotic woman pops up like a warrior, in a scant leather outfit, holding a machine gun.  You can't help but cheer on the top of your lungs when that scene comes up.  If you're a movie critic, you can pick apart this movie in many ways, but its flaws are what charmed me about the film.  The acting is bad, but it was bad to the extent where it made me smile (rather than cringe).  The dialogue is also bad, but it made me laugh, and it sort of parodies the cheesy lines we hear in many trashy horror flicks.  Cool death scenes, hot chicks, great moments of humor, one great nude scene. What more can I ask for?  I'm not quite sure, but I felt the movie was missing something, which prevented it from making it any more than a slightly above-average film--at least in my opinion.  There was a certain aura of dullness to it, though I still had a good deal of fun. Nevertheless, it's definitely worth watching and worth renting on DVD (there's a great commentary and a great documentary about the Jason flicks). You pretty much have nothing to lose.  But I really wish they could've played "Let the Bodies Hit the Floor" somewhere in the film, because it sounded awesome in the trailer.  Once again, I must say:  Stop playing music in trailers if it's not gonna be in the film!  My score:  6 (out of 10)

Review title: Weak Event Horizon meets Friday The 13th
Review_body: This one was TOTALLY UNNECESSARY. Okay, it is a bit interesting and we get to see some iconic stuff like Adrienne's death or Kay-Em-14 character, but NO. It's a cringe story and the ambiance is nothing compared to other sci-fi movies.

Jason's in space killing people. Why on earth not? Jason X had the good fortune of following 1993's Jason Goes to Hell, where the formula had already been flushed down the toilet. Jason Goes to Hell was so bad and by comparison Jason X fares extremely well. So, why not send Jason to space; I mean, it's something he hadn't done before. If you put yourself in the right frame of mind and realize that you have to have zero expectations; Jason X goes down rather well, surprisingly enough.In an amusing prologue, featuring David Cronenberg no less, Jason gets frozen along with a female scientist slated to be his next victim. A crew aboard a spaceship in the year 2455 picks them up and head back to Earth 2 (since our beloved planet earth is no longer habitable). Soon, Jason comes to life again and starts killing off the crew members in his usually grisly fashion. So, what does the year 2455 hold in store for us that's similar today? Well, the most striking thing is that teenagers and adults alike don't seem to get any smarter as time goes by.While this is a silly film, and I mean SILLY (writing, idiotic characters, sci-fi ripoffs from countless films etc. ) Jason X is an enjoyable time waster for fans of the series. His kills are quite inventive and well done, in fact the whole production values of the film were impressive, compared to it's low budget. The whole notion of Jason being in space is of course ludicrous but I must admit it turned out to be a lot more enjoyable than I thought.

I watched this because I wanted all the film's. Interesting idea. The blonde guy is a twit. The story and action are good. Kane is the best Jason. I thought he was going to spare the blonde guy but no. Oh well. The thing that bugs me is that even after all these years They can't figure out how to kill him. I get the feeling that there is another film due.

Review title: In the past or in the future it all the same for dumb people
Review_body: For the fan Jason X was the worst thing that has ever happened to Friday the 13th series but as a guy that find Camp Crystal Lake freaking boring the idea of taking Jason Voorhees to outer space where he can slice dumb futuristic teenager into pieces sound bloody genius to me.All characters in this movie is just an object for Jason to testing his new workout location and upgrade beside Kay-Em 14 an android girl who pull out while a fight with Jason that both incredibly stupid and awesome at the same time.Of all the Friday the 13th movie I really can find myself watch Jason X again if i want a quick fun slasher time

Review title: I admit a guilty pleasure of mine I never thought this is a terrible film
Review_body: SPOILER: Uber Jason in outer space I don't mind the film and it is a guilty pleasure of mine. I saw this movie in the video store 11 years ago when I was in high school I saw the VHS cover of the film and I saw it on DVD. So finally I got this film on Blu-ray disc just finish it watching it today and I must say it is not a bad film I like it a lot. Like I said it is a guilty pleasure of mine. I know a lot of people hate this film I don't. I think is MILES way better then Jason Goes to Hell and Miles way better movie then Hellraiser: Bloodline that was in outer space this movie is just better.7.years ago when I become a fan of Supernatural I heard that Jared Padalecki will be in the reboot Friday the 13th movie I rushed to see this movie. I watch Friday the 13th the original, Friday the 13th Part 2, the (2009) reboot and this film Jason X and yes I like it.I thought this movie will copy Alien and Aliens but it didn't copy any of those films it was solid and it was original it had his own story. I didn't thought this movie was bad I thought it was an interesting story that had a good action and a good slasher kills.Lexa Doig was an alright as the final girl tough it was a science fiction film it was still good and I will still watching it. Lexa Doig was in The Tracker with Casper Van Dien and I liked that action film I haven't seen in a while.Jason Voorhees returns with a new look, a new machete, and his same murderous attitude as he is awakened on a spaceship in the 25th century.Lexa Doig worked in facility Crystal Lake in which they capture Jason Voorhees but he kills everyone and escapes but Rowan Lafontaine (Lexa Doig) freeze him and her self in 2008. The year is now 2455 and a new crew members on a ship unfroze those two only too realize they unfroze Jason Voorhees unstoppable killing machine. Now a new group of soldiers tries to defeat Jason who later becomes Uber Jason.Lisa Ryder was great, sexy and really hot as Kay-Em 14 I liked her, she really kicked Jason's ass and she shot him to death ha ha.So it is scary? No. Is it a good movie? No. Is it fun? VERY.I also forgot this movie is reference to Demolition Man (1993) my all time favorite futuristic action Stallone film. In which they were mention to Lexa Doig's character that she was in Cryo it references to Cryo-prison it is similar to Demolition Man.Jason X is a 2001 American science fiction slasher film produced and directed by James Isaac. It is the tenth installment in the Friday the 13th film series and stars Kane Hodder in his fourth and final film appearance as the undead mass murderer Jason Voorhees and his futuristic counterpart, Uber Jason.This movie get's a C+ 6/10 wasn't that bad of a film but wasn't a great Jason slasher film either, but still it is my all time favorite guilty pleasure of mine.I have enjoyed this movie and I had fun watching it. Honestly I have enjoyed this movie much more then I did Friday the 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan but that is just my opinion It is my favorite guilty pleasure of mine.

Review title: Hey, at least it's better than the last one
Review_body: Easily the fifth or sixth time Friday the 13th has jumped the shark, this time pulling a double corkscrew backflip along the way. Following in the hallowed footsteps of Leprechaun 4, Hellraiser: Bloodline and Critters 4, this installment finds Jason cryogenically frozen for four hundred years and defrosted aboard a lightly-staffed spacecraft. No explanation is offered for his abrupt return from the depths of the nether, where he was unceremoniously dumped at the end of Jason Goes to Hell, though I'm not sure that really would've made a difference. This is a willfully stupid playground for half-baked science fiction ideas, terrible wardrobe choices and budget special effects; a cut-rate production that would feel right at home on the Sci-Fi Channel at 3am. Predictable to the end, it touches all the bases with gratuitous nudity, shallow characters, mysterious returns from certain doom and a truckload of dismemberments / decapitations / deaths. The only thing we're missing is the trademarked screeching cat fake-out, presumably because no self-respecting animal would be seen in such a production. Apart from one fleeting moment of self-deprecating parody near the end - which is totally out of place, but admittedly had me howling - there's no reason for this to exist. It's the kind of thing that would've thrived on the bootleg circuit, akin to Roger Corman's unreleased Fantastic Four, but by actually sending it to theaters, New Line took the wind out of those sails. The best thing I can say here is, hey, at least it's better than the last one.

Review title: A festival of the ridiculous that turns out to be unintentional entertainment (or not?), Jason X is a bizarre turn for the Friday The 13th series
Review_body: Every successful franchise, especially the 80s horror ones, has its movie that symbolizes the rock bottom. Nightmare Hour 6: Freddy's Death (1991) was from the Freddy Krueger series Halloween 6: The Last Revenge (1995) was from Michael Myers and well... Jason X (2001) was from the Friday franchise -Fair 13. Once the most prolific of the genre, the series started in 1980 reached its tenth film already tired and lazy. The penultimate film had been a bombshell and New Line's official plans were to produce the long-awaited Freddy vs Jason (2003) clash. However, the crossover was a long and time-consuming process.That's when Sean S. Cunningam, the franchise's producer and director of the first movie, said they needed a new movie to keep the character in people's mouths, but no one had an idea for the tenth of Friday the 13th. Not until Todd Farmer arrives, giving the idea of taking the Hockey Mask Killer into space. He forgets Jason is in hell alongside Freddy Krueger. In this space incursion by the antagonist who murdered more than a hundred people in Crystal Lake (and in New York as well), there is no direct connection with Jason Goes To Hell - Last Friday, the previous episode of the franchise. We don't know how and why, but Jason seems to have escaped hell and bitter his last days at a Research Facility in Crystal Lake.At the site, the young man is under the supervision of Rowan (Lexa Doig), but his superiors want to move Jason away because of some financial investments. This sovereignty appears in the skin of the exceptional David Cronenberg, filmmaker responsible for classics such as A Mosca and Scanners, who here makes a point to give credibility to his film colleagues. What we expected happens: Jason manages to escape and Rowan will have to face him, until after an unsafe procedure, both end up in a cryogenic suspension compartment, becoming two frozen specimens found only in 2455, thanks to the incursion of the archaeologist Lowe (Jonathan Potts) and his troupe of students. They inhabit Earth 2, given that our planet is destroyed.Jason is taken into space along with Rowan. Both go through the resuscitation attempt. With the girl, the process is successful. Jason, as the killing machine we've known and loved since the 1980s, also resurrects, throwing the party right at the arrival ceremony, attacking researcher Adrienne (Kristi Angus), a character created in honor of the final girl of the franchise's first film. Death became one of the most talked about in the series: he first freezes the girl's face, then smashes it into several pieces, like a crystal. Insane, but no less fun.Jason Voorhees' tenth film has a certain quality to its making, almost like an old episode of Stargate or Andromeda; not by chance, the actress Lexa Doig is the protagonist. It's more of a sci-fi parody B than a horror movie itself, so much so that Jason X doesn't make much sense within the official chronology, after all, Jason should be in hell and not being used as a guinea pig for scientists in the future, so when one of the character's comments that "a creature that can't be killed would be too valuable to dump," we know that Todd Farmer's text is a metalanguage about the franchise itself and its endless sequels.Jason X has everything fans of the series would want to see: violent deaths, beautiful women, tributes to the franchise's movies (including a sex scene), really strong enemies and even an updated look for the famous killer. Kane Hodder, highly inspired, brings a strong Jason, with his deep breathing and quite menacing. Here, he has hair, but not the ridiculous strands from the previous movie. He also no longer lets out the grunts that destroyed the ninth part, nor does he throw his victims everywhere. He kills without mercy, rips his head off, cuts it into pieces and even faces a virtual monster, in one of the funniest scenes in the movie.Taking advantage of the futuristic environment, Jason faces the agility of a cyborg extremely prepared for a fight with the assassin and also participates in a virtual reality, set in 1980, in Crystal Lake. With the repetition of the famous little song (reedited in the second film), Jason beats the sleeping bags with the girls against a tree, mercilessly. The scene was inspired by Friday the 13th - Part VII, where Kane Hodder ended up getting very tired of carrying the heavy bags over and over again. According to the original screenplay, the idea was to make Jason reunite with his mother in 1980 and kill her, showing his total irrationality and malice. The scene ended up not being filmed.It's fun and bizarre to see how Farmer mixes typical space exploration movie characters with the banal clichés of the Friday 13 slasher movie. Where else would you imagine seeing horny teenage scientists on the deck of a spaceship? Or maybe that the ship's officers all wear tops? Again, it's more of a parody than a serious movie, and Farmer really pushes the envelope by exploring an android character (played by Melyssa Ade), but it's fun when the story requires a heavy fight between artificial intelligence (with machine guns and costumes from leather) and Jason. It's a guilty pleasure of the big ones.But the quotes don't stop there: one of the characters in the film is called Adrienne, in direct reference to the actress Adrienne King, who played the heroine of the first film. At a certain point, Jason finds his old machete and decides to use it again on Prof. Lowe, the movie's comic relief, as well as the cyborg herself. Jason repeats several classic deaths from the series in this film, such as the traditional slit throat and the knife thrown from a distance; Jason's mask is removed at one point, featuring a deformed Jason who closely resembles the character in the original film.It's obvious that not everything is perfect in the film ("perfect" in the sense of "fun"). The final sequence, with Jason flying and everything, is ridiculous. The quick transformation of the assassin into "Robocop" is blamed on the bad editing (where the machine managed to develop the new mask, no one knows); and even the script fails to say that they tried to kill him anyway and failed, without mentioning the character's supernatural characteristics. Why, sometimes, he came back by macabre luck indeed; when Jason blows the ship apart from the outside and depressurization takes place, the effect ends after a victim is sucked out. Jason keeps breaking down the doors, but no one else gets pulled...among other nonsense.As Sean S. Cunigham points out in Donald R. Beck's documentary Secrets Behind the Massacre, the magic show involving the first night of horror at Crystal Lake was replaced by the special effects and CGI of this episode, which made it easier to be conceived in aesthetic aspects. The filmmaker also claims that the production was a step forward, after all, unlike the camp, it is more difficult to imagine what will happen in a plot located in a space totally different from the traditional one. It's a movie that reminds a lot of Syfy's productions. James Isaac creates a believable and sufficiently futuristic world without ever drawing much attention to himself. Of course the CGI used in some sequences (like the bizarre ant treatment) has aged terribly, but the sets and settings work. Seeing Jason in such a different context is heartening, especially when the killer uses some improvised weapons (see head freeze) to execute his victims, and some sequences involving dark places are almost capable of reminding us of Alien - or, at worst, from Alien: Resurrection.A festival of the ridiculous that turns out to be unintentional entertainment (or not?), Jason X is a bizarre turn for the Friday the 13th series, and it explores well the mix of the slasher genre and science fiction. Open-minded and unpretentious, the viewer can find plenty to enjoy.

Review title: Jason spreads the terror on board of a spaceship...
Review_body: As well as "Jason Goes To Hell: The Final Friday" this movie has no direct connection to the series. It's not as bad as that film but it's not far better though. This time the "improvement" in JASON saga was to send him to the year 2455, creating a SCI-FI movie that related to Friday THE 13TH has the JASON figure and not much else. One of the few details I really appreciated in this film was this "future JASON" which appears in the last 20 minutes, with a futuristic mask and steel armor.As many people say the series is only genuine until part IV, since then it's just a bunch of "artificial reinterpretations". Now that I already watched all the ten titles I can say that from part IV we can only save Part V and VIII in my perspective, all the rest is pure trash.

Review title: Please! In the name of Michael Myers and all that is holy...
Review_body: STOP MAKING THESE MOVIES! First this series copped the white mask from Halloween. Second it made countless dumb sequels in the name of gore and cheap money. But now, maybe earlier, it has started to repeat itself. When you can't even come up with inventive ways of killing people, especially when that is supposed to be the draw, it is time to call it a day. This series has delved into creative incest. The best part is stolen from one of the lame named predecessors, when JV bashes a CG girl infested sleeping bag into tree. It is funny, because JV is such a moron. When Friday the 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan sleeps with Jason Goes To Hell: The Final Friday, you get this dirty blonde little piece of trailer trash.P.S. Lisa, Brent Spiner called, you got some explaining to do.

Wow, this is the most ironic part in the Friday The 13th series I ever saw (I haven't been so lucky to see parts IV, VIII and IX, yet). When I heard this movie takes place in the future.... in space... I had already written it off. But, hey! The special effects are surprisingly fine, the actors are okay and there are indeed some (intentionally) funny moments (like: "This oughta do"). Of course, "Jason X" is far away from being a good movie but for horror-fans like me there's nothing to complain about.
