There's little logic and lots of gore and at least one really inventive way of killing a girl (the frozen face sequence). So, everybody who loves these never-ending horror-series à la Nightmare on Elm Street/Halloween: watch this. It's a good sequel for a change!

In the year 2455, a group of students on an trip to visit "old earth" and find two cryogenic ally frozen bodies. One is a young woman ( Lexia Doig) and the other is none other than Jason Voorhees(Hodder). They bring both bodies on board their spacecraft, where both subjects eventually thaw out and the one wearing the goalie mask goes on a murder spree.When I first heard that the 10th entry in the franchise is gonna be Jason in outer space, I thought that it sounded stupid and was gonna be rubbish but when I saw the film I was pleasantly surprised, sure it was corny and the story line is ridiculous but I loved it Jason is back and he's on form unlike the disappointing previous entry "Jason Goes To Hell".This 10th chapter in the "Friday the 13th" franchise retains the same energy as the previous entries but delivers it in a spaceship setting. You want to see Jason put "Rambo" to shame as he hunts down some ex-grunts? Right here, a-holes! Or how about Jason going mano-a-mano against a leather-clad, gun-toting female Android? You got it! Jason X has its fair share of slash and crash, but at the same time, it emanates an "Aliens" (an obvious inspiration) type of vibe. Some purists might say that's a negative thing, but I believe that after nine films, Jason needed a change of scenery like I needed a new "bootie call". They slapped old hockey-puss in space and managed to pull it off. Props to all! Okay the film is low budget but I found the special effects were pretty good, the spacecraft simple yet effective costumes are colourful. I particularly enjoyed the S&M-like outfit that Kay-Em (Ryder) sported after getting her robotic cherry popped. Nice! Our boy Jason hasn't changed much. He felt more human this time around though (he has hair!) and doesn't look like the zombie he was in part 6-7-8-9. I found Jason less menacing than he was in "Friday The 13th Part 7", but he still got the grisly job done. I also loved it when Jason gets the big terminator style makeover where he's all metal and robotic and such and such like. The fight sequence between Jason and the robot woman is definitely the highlight of the film and the kills are wicked and fresh.The good thing is that "Jason X" is just a good cheesy slasher and it doesn't pretend to be anything else but that. Yes, the good guys are weak and the film doesn't always capitalise on its groovy situations but we still get lots of explosions, kills, fights sequences, some occasional funny dialogue, some humorous situations (loved the Virtual Reality sequence) and Jason even gets to re-visit "Crystal Lake" to entertain two female campers in his own charming way.Kane Hodder (Jason) gives Jason more of a human personality this time around, but I didn't find him as threatening as he was in the previous entries. Lexa Doig (Rowan) handles her part well, but I would've liked to see her kick more ass. Lisa Ryder (Kay-Em) steals the show as the sexually curious, Kung Fu android. She has fun with the role. Jonathan Potts (Professor Rowe) does the pathetic creep thing well, but yes, he irritated me. Melyssa Ade (Janessa) is cute and her delivery is on, but her character didn't do it for me. She's kind of despicable. Peter Mensah (Sergeant Brodski) was charming as the resilient Marine. I loved every second that he was on screen. Chuck Campbell (Tsunaron) bored me as the geek and he had his moments of "weak" acting.All in all being a hardcore Jason fan I absolutely loved this entry in the Friday The 13th series, I loved the female robot, the action sequences, the kills and the over the top special effects.

Review title: In space only Jason can hear you scream!
Review_body: The tenth movie in the long running Friday the 13th series, Jason X took the series in a very different direction by putting Jason Voorhees into space aswell as four hundred years into the future where humanity now lives on earth 2 where the teenagers are still just horny idiots just waiting for Jason to kill them.Jason X is exactly the movie you expect it to be an over the top slasher movie that doesn't take itself too seriously giving it's audience exactly what they asked for an entertaining slasher movie that's just an hour and a half of Jason Voorhees killing various people in bloody entertaining ways. The special effects while dated by today's standards were actually pretty decent for a low budget slasher movie made in the early 2000s.The idea of putting Jason Voorhees in space is as crazy and silly as it sounds. This is probably the least serious entry in the Friday the 13th series to date and that's in a movie series that has had some very odd entry's which have included a copycat Jason Voorhees killer, followed by the resurrection of Jason that essentially made him an unkillable zombie, then a movie where Jason fights a girl with telekinetic powers, then Jason went to Manhattan where toxic waste turned him back into a child which was ignored in the next movie where Jason dies but comes back once again as a body snatcher creature which ends with him being sent to hell with Freddy Kreuger, after all that it's no surprise Jason went to space it's the next logical step in a series as crazy as this one.Jason X was released in 2001 but was actually filmed in 1999 and was first released in Germany in the year 2000 before it was finally released in the US in 2001. The movie was made during the Matrix craze era of the early 2000s when every movie was trying to get in on the science fiction craze brought about by the success of The Matrix.I recommend Jason X if your a fan of old school slasher movies that focus more on the death scenes and special effects it's fun, bloody and entertaining like a Jason movie should be.

In 2001 Jason X was a great film, different than the rest films in the franchise. The special effects looked great then, it was the beginning of a new century and the second year of the 2000's decade, Jason X was a modern piece by then. Today the movie is funny but the special effects looks very old. The script is decent and entertaining, the performances are fine and the direction is ok. Not amazing, but much better than part 8. A good work of this Canadian-American slasher flick.

Review title: Better than many of the previous Friday the 13th films!
Review_body: No, I'm not going to sit here and try to defend the film.  Yeah, it was a terrible film, it really was.  But I've got to say it wasn't nearly as bad as most of the previous Friday the 13th films.  This one at least has some originality to it.  I agree is was a bit of a stretch to have Jason Vorhees in space, but at least it opened some doors for some interesting and futuristic deaths, weapons, characters and what not.  I can't believe people would say this one was worse than the previous 7 films, they're all just different ways of telling the same story and virtually nothing new to look at!  At least this one was an interesting change of scenery.The acting was nothing to get excited about, but c'mon, it's the 10th movie in a horror series, what can you expect?  Besides, the movie doesn't require good acting, I'm not watching this film for acting talent.On the upside, the women in the film were very good looking.  Virtually every female in the cast was very attractive and quite nice on the eyes.Also, a lot of people said that the special effects weren't very good.  Well no, they aren't very good compared to "The Matrix" or "Jurassic Park", but for a Jason film, they were pretty darn good.  I was personally very impressed with the special effects, I'm sure the budget was pretty small for this film and somehow they pulled off some pretty good special effects. Also, before I forget, I really liked the opening title sequence in the film.  Very well done (MUCH better than ANY of the previous Friday the 13th films).The dialogue in the film was really bad, with a number of moments that just make you want to cringe because you can't believe how stupid the lines are.The whole Uber-Jason thing was stupid as all hell!  Why did they do that? Ok, I can understand the machine that fixes humans actually putting Jason back together, but why would it make him better than before?  And why, oh why, would it create a new hockey mask for him and make his whole right side out of metal?  I cannot even begin to express how stupid that is!  That aside...the make up effects were actually pretty impressive and well done.No, I wouldn't recommend this film to just anyone, but if you are a Jason fan, go ahead and watch it.  ...And if you are just a mediocre Jason fan and a sci-fi fan, then go ahead and check this one out.  In all honesty, you don't need to watch any of the previous films to understand what's going on here (it might even be better if you don't).  Although, it might be nice to watch the first two films, and they may shed some light on subject.  If, you do choose to see this film, I hope you enjoy it.  Thanks for reading,-Chris

Alrighty now.. the long awaited 10th film in the legendary "Friday the 13th" movie series hits theatres and what is the result? If you liked the previous nine you will like this one, if the hockey masked machete wielding Jason Voorhees isnt your cup of tea then you should probably avoid the latest installment in the franchise. In this film, Jason (once more played by stuntman Kane Hodder) is placed in suspended animation and winds up getting thawed out on a spaceship some 400 or so years later to wreck havoc on a hapless group of hollywood newbies who decided to audition for this film. Actualy the cast is pretty good as this sort of thing goes and the producers decided to have some fun with the concept, throwing in everything from an obvious "Alien" inspired storyline to a "Terminatrix" babe (played by Lisa Ryder, who like co-star Lexa Doig hails from the "Andromida" TV Series). Some funny bits with Jason and a pointed parody of the original film due to a virtual reality simulation (!) make this one a step above most of the efforts in this series. So, until Jason rises again, this one is a keeper for fans of slasher movies worldwide. GRADE: B+

Jason X Directed by Jim Isaac and starring Kane HodderEVIL GETS AN UPGRADEFriday the 13th meets Star Trek, when Jason Voorhees takes a step too far and jumps into space. Gone are the scares which are required for a horror film. Effects at times can be laughable and the acting is a horror all by itself. With a Shatner lookalike Captain, the badly cast actor fail to make any character decent or memorable. Best acting goes to Kane Hodder, who you don't ever see or hear. Definitely the weakest of the franchise.His unique ability to regenerate lost and damaged tissue, it's just it cries out for more research. – Dr. Wimmer (David Cronenberg)

Honestly, this is a bad film. Some of the most annoying characters in a film, most jokes never land at all, no horror, no suspense, some weird score...well, at least Jason was ok, the first scene was good and we had some good deaths.

I didn't think it could get much worse than Jason Goes to Hell but... yeah, this is bad. I'm starting to theorize why most Friday the 13th boxed sets only have 1-8. I feel like even the studio is probably ashamed of 9 & 10.And justifiably so. They're horrible.So the basic (spoiler-reduced) synopsis is:Jason gets cryogenically frozen to be thawed 400 years later so he can basically do the same thing he's done during every other movie, but in the future.The characters are unlikable, the story reeks of series fatigue and corporate greed. The movie simply has no purpose. It's missing everything that made most of the earlier entries entertaining. It's just... a hollow slasher where things keep happening, but nothing occurs that's of particular interest to the viewer.I personally disown Jason Goes to Hell and Jason X as Friday the 13th films, because they're horrendous. The eighth entry, Jason Takes Manhattan, should've been the last. Because that movie was actually fun and enjoyable.And, of course, even Freddy vs. Jason ignores this film's existence... good riddance! Never again on this one.

Review title: The 'Jason' Film That Could Have Been... Instead, It's A Bad SciFy Channel Movie From The 2000's
It's been nine years since the last Jason movie hit theaters, and while Mr. Voorhees has been away we saw the rise and fall of the post-modern slasher movie.
Review_body: Scream and I Know What You Did Last Summer showed there was new life in this sub-genre of horror, with their heroes and heroines a little smarter and wiser than the oversexed victims we saw in the first Friday the 13th and Halloween flicks. In fact, even the Halloween franchise got in on the post-modern act by having Jamie Lee Curtis return to face Michael Myers one last time in Halloween: H20 (well, until the forthcoming sequel, anyway.) So here we are in 2002 and now it's Jason's turn to get a reboot in Jason X, his tenth film and New Line Cinema's second with the character. I'll admit that I gave up watching Friday the 13th films after the third installment. I don't count myself as a big fan of this genre because I know Jason is gonna survive each film, no matter what happens. From speaking to friends and acquaintances who have seen all the Friday the 13th  movies out there, part of the appeal the Friday films offer to slasher fans is the fun in watching Jason off his prey in new and creative ways. For that reason alone fans of Jason will probably enjoy Jason X as it offers plenty of grisly kills that haven't been seen before. But does it offer anything else besides an impressive body count? After a cool opening credit sequence where the camera is inside Jason, we see the homicidal hockey mask wearing maniac has finally been captured and is being held in solitude. Rowan (Lexa Doig) doesn't want Dr. Wimmer to take Jason away from the secure facilities at the Crystal Lake Research Facility. Of course, Jason breaks free and offs everyone there except for our heroine who manages to freeze Jason (and herself) just before she has a date with the Grim Reaper. Time passes and 500 years later Earth is a forgotten wasteland. A group of visiting history students uncover the entombed Jason and Rowan, take them back into their spaceship and thaw them out. Now that the first act of the picture is out of the way, the carnage truly begins. As far as Friday the 13th films go, Jason X has some superior assets. The set design of the spaceship Grendel sure looks cool, and the visual FX by Toronto-based Toybox are pretty kick-ass all around (especially for one scene where soldiers play in a holodeck). The actors all do a good enough job given the material they're working with -- you know, have sex, scream, collect paycheck -- and the characters are likeable enough. Kane Hodder's Jason is, well, Jason and he does what one expects him to do when a big homicidal maniac wields a machete. Extra kudos are given to Lisa Ryder, who plays the android Kay-Em 14. Ryder's mechanical character comes across very different than her Andromeda starship captain role she's best known for, more subdued and likeable. I've read elsewhere that Jason X has by far the largest body count of any previous films, and that certainly gives an incentive for horror fans to go check it out. But... somewhere along the way I think Jason X veered left when it should have veered right. This should be a film that focused on capturing a wider audience, say people like me who fell away from the Friday the 13th series because, after awhile, every Friday movie seemed the same. While credit needs to be given to screenwriter Todd Farmer for going that extra step into the unknown and taking Jason off-planet and placing him into a sci-fi setting, I think Farmer needed to take the material that one extra and dangerous step further: into satire. Sam Raimi did this with Evil Dead II and the resulting fusion of horror and comedy paid off in a huge way. Evil Dead II is considered a classic by just about every horror fan, and I was hoping Jason X could utilize this approach to make Jason Voorhees' approach more appealing and less familiar. Farmer and director James Isaac try hamming it up in later scenes but by this time the tone of the movie has already been established, and the result are moments that should have been funny but instead you roll-your-eyes and groan out loud. Also following into the realm of missed opportunity was the chance to play with some sci-fi clichés we've all seen since the first Friday the 13th film came out more than 20 years ago. There are some in the picture, like Rowan asking about "beaming off" the ship or the Aliens-like vibe coming from the Marines who are sent to hunt down Jason, but you're left wishing there were more of these, or better executed for more laughs. One stand-out example is the recreation of a Camp Crystal Lake hologram circa 1980 and Jason's interaction with it. Again, it works because it's played for the right amount of laughs and drama. The audience is already in on the joke; after nine films, we know what Jason's reaction would be but it's still fun to see it happen.When we're finally introduced to the new, upgraded Jason 2.0, there's surprisingly little of him in action before the film needs to be wrapped up. Of course, room for a sequel is left at the end of the film and it would be interesting to see where New Line decided to go in a future chapter.> Ultimately your mileage on Jason X will vary depending upon what you want to get out of it. If you're looking for a scary movie that winks at the audience a la Scream, you'll probably be disappointed. At the same time, die-hard fans will likely get more enjoyment from seeing the return of Jason and the new kills he notches along the way. And if you're someone like me who was hoping for more re-thinking of the entire franchise and the horror icon Jason Voorhees has become in the genre, you're split down the middle.As much as I dig that poster design and the concept of re-inventing this franchise and finding a way to appease the traditional Friday the 13th fan, Jason X remained a mixed bag for me.

This was a good movie. I really liked it. I'm not much of a Jason fan but like this was a lot better then the other ones by far. The music really sucked in this movie. They could of had better music. But other than that I personally think this was the second best Friday the 13th movie. Other than the first. I recommend this movie to anyone who loves the whole Friday the 13th series. This a whole lot better than the other Jason movies by far.

'Jason X' is not your average 'Friday the 13th' film.It takes the series and adds something entirely different.Jason Voorhees has been to Camp Crystal Lake and even Manhatten.Now, he's somewhere that no one would ever expect him to go.Is he in the North Pole? No.Is he in the desert? No.Is he in space? As corny as it sounds, yes.I actually enjoyed 'Jason X'.The kills are entertaining and Jason is still fun to watch.If there is anything bad about this film, it's the acting.Not every line of the movie is bad, but some are just ridiculous and unnecessary.Still, I found 'Jason X' to be a fun and entertaining slasher film with a great performance by the machete wielding maniac Jason Voorhees.

This movie here is pure gold. Jason takes his reign of terror a step farther by taking on a research facility, and then a crew aboard a spaceship in the year 2455. The characters in this movie were great. I got to like some and really hate others. They were very convincing. Jason is played yet again by Kane Hodder (thankfully!). There were some very good kills, and this was a whole new setting for Jason. But it worked very well. I personally liked Uber-Jason, although many hated him. Come on people, it had to be done! Its not like a permanent new thing for him, seriously. The effects were very good for a movie such as this. There were some very interesting scenes as well. And Jason always managed to come back on top here. 8/10 for a great Jason movie.

Sometimes long pumped out horror franchises head to space, like Leprechaun and Hellraiser, and the distinguished Jason couldn't escape it either. Finally, this is the last Friday-the-13th related movie I haven't seen. Low hopes and some excitement for a decent body rack was what I went in with. So, 25th century has the people living on Earth 2, but a single greedy doctor's and his uncannily 20th-century-alike flock of students exploration ship has just picked up a valuable relic on Earth 1. Guess one time. The plot is essentialy "Alien", just replace the xenomorph with Jason. Most of "Jason X" is what you would expect, a loud, glorious, stoopid mess, full of shiny and uninspired sets, completed with digital violence taking over practical effects, and a costume design that raises eyebrows. Protagonist characters are very cliché, not the smartest bunch and are very expendable, which Jason continuously makes sure of. My biggest complaint, really, is not enough diversity in the kills and gore section, or the stuff that could compensate for the overall silliness. Other than that, "Jason X" is a reasonably self-aware flick that spends almost all of its time racking up body count, sometimes so monotonously that boredom is born. Here and there a joke is inserted. A spoof on the franchise itself, the entire slasher genre? Maybe, but what does it change. If nothing else, it's at least entertaining. 4/10.

How did the written script of Jason going into space with time travel even get accepted by studio's in the first place? That really shows the odd time and lunacy of studio idea's about horror films back in the early 2000s. With that said it could have been a complete disaster, and having seen the film numerous times there is almost an enjoyable aspect about it even though it's a poor film, the definition of a guilty pleasure I suppose. The beginning is great, we have Jason tied up, with a good looking actress, Lexa Doig, playing a scientist as the main lead, and then the legendary David Cronenberg as a quick cameo. However, once the plot turns into the mindless space odyssey, the film goes downhill. The jokes are terrible, action sequences are fake looking, it has terrible acting performances and the idea for little nano-bugs to create Jason's metal amour, just awful. I understand those who'd like it just for the senselessness to it but overall the movie is one big mess and regret.

Man, people are so stupid. Giving this movie a bad review? If you do, you obviously didn't get.. uhm, anything. This movie is extremely entertaining! Cheesy? Yes. Of course, it's Jason in space for Petes sake!Lets break it down. Let me list everything that is good: *Jason is awesome. He just looks real good. *The kills are excellent. This one has some of the best kills in the whole series. *The pacing is super. Never boring. *The budget is quite high, movie looks really good. Effects are good. *Acting is satisfactory, and satisfactory is all we need in this case.So, what more do you want? Oh, more character development? Give it a rest. We don't want that. We want an awesome Jason killing lots of pretty young people. That we get.The only thing I don't like a 100% is the cyborg-chick. She brings it down a tad. Other than that, this is just very good fun. And since it's set in the future, they can make how ever many sequels (happening before this one in the Friday the 13th-timeline) as they want! Smart thinking!Shame on the douche bags giving this a low rating. I feel kind of sorry for them.

Review title: You know they've jumped the shark when...
Review_body: Jason X is the 10th entry in the Friday the 13th series, even though part 9 was entitled THE FINAL Friday. In this entry, Jason is locked up in a containment center in the year 2010. He ends up escaping and being cryogenically frozen. He awakes aboard a spaceship in 2455 and begins killing the people on board. While not as terrible as Part 7, this movie is really bad. The writers had to have run out of earthly ideas in order to come up with something as stupid as putting him in space in the future. I'm just glad they didn't put aliens aboard the ship.The acting in this movie is about as pathetic as it gets. One of the lead roles in the movie was played by the guy from the Expedia.com commericals. Awesome...You might think that people from the 25th century would be a little more advanced but uh...No, they're not. They're just as stupid as the people from the 80's slasher movies were.The special effects was a real cop out in this movie. This is the first Friday film that's used CGI for blood and gore. The plot of the film, as I've mentioned before, was retarded. A scene where they tried to reference earlier Friday the 13th films using holograms backfired by being utterly retarded looking. Everything Jason does in this movie just makes you laugh at how ridiculous the whole concept is. Thankfully, any Friday movies made after this will take place in modern times.1/10

Review title: Jason goes space age....with sexy results
Review_body: Simpsons tie in, couldn't resist. Apologies for the misleading summary, because there is nothing sexy about this movie, but it is still enjoyable.This time Jason is set loose on a space ship full of rather silly people, hot girls and action heroes. THis film certainly has its moments. The effects are decent, the kills are fun and Jason's science fiction upgrade at the film's conclusion is well done.This probably won't be liked by older Friday fans, but if you were born a little down the Friday chronology give this one a shot. It gives Jason a little bit of personality and some cool toys to play with.

You can not keep a good man down and Jason is back in top form.  After ripping off mostly the "Alien" series, Jason proves that the worst monsters are created right here on good old Earth.I don't think they should have "updated" him.  The original retro look made him even more menacing.Word of advice to the producers:  If you plan a number eleven, kill more good looking naked chicks or just have them cavort naked!Smashing good time for lovers of gore!

Ah Jason, the best serial killer of all time. The man takes a beating, and stabbing, and bullets, and baseball bats, and weed-whackers, and flipped over car accidents and keeps on ticking...somehow. Yet he always finds his trusty machete to talk when his mouth cannot.Set up in space after being cryonically frozen with a certain victim, he is awaken to find himself on a space station and fresh new meat! Some of the scenes, like when he knifes the guy when he opens the door, are priceless. The scene with the two "premarital sex" girls was funny when he beat one with the other.It does get strange with the new armor and face and he seems different. Instead of taking bullets like normal, they deflect off him like in Terminator 2. Plus the set seemed too much like Star Trek.Instead of infusing him with new tech, I would have had him kill a bunch of Trekkies in space. Would have made this into a good film instead of the mediocre one that it was. The ending was odd, but no stranger than some others. "C+"

The one in space.Admittedly, I may have jumped the shark calling Part 8 the worst of the franchise. If only I knew what I know now. Times were simpler back then. I should've savored that guy getting his head punched off into a dumpster, because Jason X may actually be the worst big budget movie of all time.Sure 14 million isn't close to the big budgets of today, but it has the biggest budget of the entire series! (Not counting Freddy vs Jason which has a 25 million dollar budget.) Part 6 is still a legitimately fun movie that was made for less then 6 million. This had nearly 3 times the budget of that and it looks like a student film. Did they hire people that were fresh out of high school to save money??It's set nearly 500 years after...who knows when because Jason went to hell in the last one, so how did he get out? When did he get out? Or are they ignoring that one and making this as a sequel to Jason Takes Manhattan? If that is the case that would be quite fitting. Having two of the worst horror movies ever made directly linked would be a happy coincidence. Anyway, this takes place in 2455 or something because why not?You'd think doing this would be very creatively freeing. You could have Jason wandering around fantastical sets, using futuristic weapons, and maybe you could have the humans of the future be pacifists so Jason could go on an absolute killing spree. But no, instead it's just Friday the 13th in a metal death trap they prentend is a space ship. Which you never buy, even for a second. The film has a blatant lack of imagination to the point of lunacy.Even Jason is completely uninspired in this. He wanders around slashing people with a regular machete. But it's futuristic because it's slightly curved and has holes for some reason. That's really the biggest issue here, a lack of creativity. It's the future because everything is metal and people wear slightly more tattered clothes, but there's still midterms. The sets look absurdly cheap, the cinematography is ugly and constantly underexposed, and the performances are series worst across the board.It's baffling how bad this is actually, and quite difficult to verbalize. This series has been quite the disappointment on the whole but this brings it to unwatchable levels. Even the worst entries have a certain camp or goofiness that keeps them afloat. There is no such thing here. It takes itself deadly serious, which is odd considering it features a robot trying to put fake nipples on to please her programmer. The dialogue is terrible, the premise sucks, the characters are annoying, the kills are bland, the sets are hideous, and it's inexcusably cheap looking for being the most expensive in the franchise (minus the next two).

+Possible Spoilers+No. No. No. Jason X is not "awesome" or even watch-able. It is horrible. It appears that Friday the 13th XIII (Jason Takes Manhattan), did a terrible thing by "motivating" Jason to wonder off from the Camp. Lets get real, Slasher films almost always succeed and usually have a large audience.....but Jason X isn't even Slasher. It is the worst worthless Science Fictional movie ever.Not only that, the scares were too cheap for television. The makers try to make Jason the same scary guy he was back a Camp.1 out of 10 If you want to see a good movie, rent Sleep Away Camp, Friday the 13th 1 - 7, Skinned Alive, Dead Next Door, Puppet Master, or, a new favorite, THE RING. For recommendations on other titles, please check the other movies I have commented on by clicking on my name above this comment section.

SPOILERSJason X is about Jason getting frozen and getting thawed out in 2400 and goes on a killing spree. This one is just the others, except this one is in space. Towards the end, Jason becomes Uber-Jason. My favorite death in this when the girl's head is frozen and is smashed against the wall and shatters. That was sort of disgusting. They kill Jason but then he comes back as Uber-Jason and nothing can destroy him. But they blow the place that he's in up and he floats into space and lands in the lake while the 3 surviving people are safely in a escape pod. But when he falls in the lake a couple thought he was a shooting star. Then you see his mask in the lake. The end. Overall, this is just a high-tech slasher film.6/10

Review title: Big, dumb and stoopid, but fun
Review_body: Let's face it, if you're going to rent one of the later movies in a slasher movie series, you'd be an idiot to expect high art. The fact that this is the tenth movie in the Friday the 13th franchise, the most knuckle-draggingly, ball-scratchingly cretinous 'horror' series of all time AND it's set in space doesn't exactly suggest that this'll be an all-time classic, but it's a good fun way to kill an hour and thirty minutes nonetheless.Okay, the plot is so thin even a slight breeze would make it disintegrate and the horror element is practically non-existent but then Jason movies abandoned that long ago in favour of just providing dumb escapism with inventive and bloody death scenes, which this film certainly provides. People are sliced in half, impaled on large spikes, blown up, one poor woman even getting her head dunked in liquid nitrogen and shattered on a desk, but the characters are so one-dimensional and it's so cheesy you're more likely to laugh than scream. And I defy you to watch the scene when Jason gets transformed into 'Uber Jason' for the first time and not have a colossal grin traverse your face. There's even a later scene which pokes fun at the earlier movie's clichés with a hilarious "beating one camper to death with the other" sequence.This is not The Exorcist, it's not The Omen, it's even a very long way away from the original Friday The 13th, but as director James Isaac has said, "it's just fun." Get your mates round, pop open a beer, disengage brain and you've got a very entertaining ninety minutes.

Review title: New idea... but rest is crap.
Review_body: To put it simply enough, 'JasonX' is a spicy mixture of all the cheapest entertaining aspects of cinema. It's got space, mindless sci-fi, androids, borg sex, sensuality, action, gore and finally, Jason Voorhees. The basic plot is really dumb, but works in a way to give a new touch to this 10th installment of "Friday the 13th" series. Because at least it is well-known that no director would take a risk of making a Jason movie again at Camp Crystal Lake, after "Jason Goes to Hell" literally murdered the famous slasher franchise. So we needed something new. Okay, "JasonX" IS something new. But it should have been way better.I think it's useless to point out keyholes in this disgusting story. But one thing must be said about the 'uber-Jason' -- it is totally crap. the old Jason with the hockey mask was way much cooler. Please, if any one of you plan another "Friday the 13th" movie, don't bring this uber-Jason. And cast Kane Hodder. He's the best Jason ever.

Review title: Jason SUX would be a better title. 3/10
Review_body: How hard would it have been to make this film fun?  Not very hard in my opinion.  All I ask for is so very little with this type of film. Sadly, Jason X is pretty damn awful.  Out of the entire movie, there are two scenes I liked.  The first scene is involves a neat death.  Jason shoves a chick's head into a liquid that makes her head freeze, then he smashes it.  The next scene, and my favorite, involves Jason trapped in virtual reality.  The scenario is at Crystal Lake, and it involves two women who want to "drink beer, smoke pot, and have premarital sex" with Jason.  The way he ends up killing them is hysterical.The rest of the movie blows.  If you like gore, you might like it.  If you like anything authentic, stay away.

I'd like to start this review off with a little question: What do you get when you combine STAR TREK with Friday the 13th?... Well, what do you get?... Wanna take a guess? JASON X of course! I'd love to see what the planning phase was like for this movie. Imagine a bunch of filmmakers sitting around: "Where can we set this latest Jason movie?" "Ooh, I know... how about in the Wild West?" "Na!" "What if Jason turns up in LA and starts killing gang..." "Meh!" "Ooh. Ooh, I know... Jason onboard a ship!" "Hello? JASON TAKES MANHATTAN?!" "No, no... a SPACE ship!" "WE LOVE IT... here's $10 Million!!!" So, in a half-cocked, hair-brained plot device, Jason winds up on a space ship several centuries in the future. And he pretty much does what he's always done. Stalking around and killing people. There are absolutely no interesting characters. The dialogue is eye-rolling atrocious. And it all feels so shoddy. Like an early episode of STAR TREK, but without the camp quality. There is one cool thing about this one however, Jason gets a solid metal mask! Other than that, this film is worthy of a photon torpedo carpet bombing!!!

This film is basically Jason in Space.This movie massively divided fans. Some loved the innovation but some hated it to such an extent that they viewed it as the worst in the series. Yes, they even hated it more than Part 5: A New Beginning.But I loved this movie. I even went to see it a bunch of times during it's original release.Theres so much to love. The claustrophobia of the spacecraft, the tongue in cheek humour, the nerdy aspects of the film's vision (check out the eye operation on Jason and the way that injuries like severed limbs are remedied).Theres also an amazing cameo by David Cronenberg thats worth the price of admission alone.With this installment being based in space theres many nods to satify the most ardant sci-fi fanboys. Least not Lisa Ryder who was a star of Andromeda. Her android character is a great addition to the cast.Uber Jason is a sight to behold! And check out the liquid nitrogen kill. It's one of the best in the whole series.Highly recommended.

Man this one's really bad. Jason X is the tenth film in a series that (at the time) was going downhill. In fact, the series became a joke when Paramount sold the franchise to New Line Cinema. Anyways, the plot for this is that Jason gets frozen, and no one discovers him until 2455. By this time, Earth no longer exists and everyone lives on a planet called Earth II. Jason gets brought to life by a group of students/teachers that went to Earth to explore the land or something. He starts killing people on board the ship. That's basically it.There is so much bad about this film. The acting is horrendous, worse than any other Friday flick if you can believe it! I hate the turn this franchise took when New Line started making these films. It's all sci-fi. Jason Goes to Hell was a cheap version of Invasion of the Body Snatchers. And this movie is basically Aliens except substitute the ugly creature with Jason Voorhees. Friday the 13th films were originally scary and creepy horror/slasher films set in the woods. Parts 1-4 were amazing because they were simple. Even parts 5-8 were better then this Andromeda/Star Trek rip off.Jason X is kind of insulting to the series. It gets marks for Kane Hodder and one murder in particular. Jason freezes a woman's head and then smashes it in a thousand pieces. One of the more unique 'Friday' kills in the series. But overall, I just hate the direction of the series. Putting horror icons in space NEVER works. Pinhead in Hellraiser Bloodline, Leprechaun in Lep 4, hell even the Critters went to space in part 4. Those sequels were awful and this sequel is awful. EASILY the worst of the series.2/10

"This sucks on so many levels!" In the horror genre, you have bad movies and then you have bad movies that know they are bad movies. "Jason X" is the latter. With nine films in the franchise, there is simply nowhere to go but upwards, and that's exactly where the tenth "Friday The 13th" (get it, Jason "X"?) takes us. Like Pinhead and Leprechaun before him, Jason is thrusted into the outer reaches of space and resumes his slaughter of bad characters aboard a cheap looking spacecraft. However, unlike previous slashers gone skyward, Jason's adventure in space is actually an enjoyable trip.First things first, this is not a scary, suspenseful or even remotely serious horror film. If you are hoping to squeeze any genuine thrills out of this movie, don't bother. However, if you are a lifelong "Friday The 13th" fan who has seen enough of Crystal Lake and doesn't take one's self too seriously, then saddle up and enjoy the best Jason movie in a long while. That's right, I said it. Most people are wound too tight and take their precious genre favorites too seriously, but not me. When I want to unwind on a Friday night, have a few beers and turn my brain off, I find there is nothing more suiting than "Jason X". With it's winning combination of nudity, bloodshed, nostalgia (sleeping bags, anyone?) and sense of humor, it doesn't matter that some parts of the film are a bit dodgy. Despite the ridiculous premise -- a group of students find a frozen, hockey-masked, machete clutching meat-bag and thaw him out on the way home -- and the lack of substantial special effects (those exteriors were a JOKE) there is still quite a bit of juice in this installment. Kane Hodder is back as Jason for what would unfortunately be his final round. Hodder goes all out, playing the uber-angry Jason that he created for "The New Blood" and even manages to make a ridiculous cyborg version of Jason seem menacing. Director James Isaac, a David Cronenberg (who cameos in this flick) protégé, delivers an unusually (for this franchise) stylish show, and despite the meager production values, gets the job done effectively. The movie looks good, even when it looks bad, if that makes any sense. It also helps that the movie was built off a script by a Joe-blow nobody fan in Todd Farmer. Farmer apparently loves Jason as much as he watches the SciFi channel, and it shows. You'll have a blast catching all the call-backs to previous movies and the little inside jokes that only a well-versed fan could possibly catch. Now, as you're reading this review, you're probably asking yourself "What's the downside of this film?" Well, I'm not sorry to say this; There is nothing wrong with this film. You go into a movie like "Jason X" -- the ninth sequel in an overly saturated franchise, which finds the title character in space -- and what do you honestly expect? If you can, God forbid, suspend disbelief, stop taking yourself and the films seriously for 90 minutes, you too will have a blast with "Jason X".

These are the voyages of the Starship Voorhees. Yep, Friday the 13th Part 10 sees Jason in space, in the future. Seriously, folks, you may think I am making this up, but it's all true. Every damn word. See, Jason's body has been cryogenically frozen and, far into the future, it is discovered and thawed out. Big mistake. Jason awakens, reclaiming his machete and, after being vamped up into some sort of half mutant, half cyborg, once more sets about his slicing and dicing antics for our enjoyment. Now, here's the thing: anyone who complains about this movie is genuinely moronic. This is the 10th movie in the series. if you don't like them, don't watch them. Watching it and then complaining is like ordering a pizza then griping that you don't like cheese. Oh, and there's plenty of that here, too. The sci-fi twist is neat, and serves well as an excuse to reanimate Our Hero, and Jason's Borged up new look is pretty damn cool. The last twenty minutes descends into your usual running, screaming, chopping scenario, but it's to be expected. David Cronenberg puts in a cameo near the start, too, to lend the movie an air of respectability. An average slasher, then, but with at least a dash of originality.
Based on R1 DVDLeave your brain at the door or better yet drown it in alcohol with a few smart ass friends, it's the only way your going to enjoy this one.5/10 brain dead

Review:
'Jason X' is an American slasher film directed by Jim Isaac. It is the tenth installment in the 'Friday the 13th' film series. Why not take the franchise into space? It seems like the most logical step after not being able to create a good film since the first one.
In the year 2010, Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder) is captured by the United States government and held at the Crystal Lake Research Facility. Government scientist Rowan LaFontaine (Lexa Doig) decides to place Jason in frozen stasis after several failed attempts to kill him. A breach is made, and Rowan is frozen alongside Jason for 455 years. Now aboard a ship in the far future they are both regenerated, and Jason continues his killing.
This is the tenth film in this series, and it's the 21 Century. Why can we still not get good actors? That's not to say the acting was bad, it was like it is in all of these movies, cheesy but suitable for what the actors are trying to accomplish. It's sad to see Kane Hodder leave after his fourth and final appearance in this film, he is my favorite Jason by far, really bringing this character to new levels.
I know that this isn't the best movie, and it does have a lot wrong with it realism wise and with continuity. God is it entertaining though! There's so much to love. The claustrophobia of the spacecraft, the tongue in cheek humour, the nerdy aspects of the film's vision. If nothing else, you need to appreciate the boldness in Jim Isaac to do a movie like this.
Overall, this may just be a guilty pleasure of mine, I know critics hated this one even more than 'Friday the 13th: A New Beginning' which I do not understand at all. If nothing else, this movie is so entertaining and true to the character of Jason you can forgive all the cheesy humor and unnecessary scenes that should have been cut. Watch this movie and have fun, that's what it's for.
3.5/5

I won't waste time pointing out the 1001 illogical plot holes.  Anyone who goes to see slasher trash expecting logic deserves to get burned.The movie starts out well, with jason held in a secret containment facility after numerous attempts to execute him have failed.  Atmospheric design and some good visuals.  The problems arise when he gets thawed out 450 years in the future on board a spaceship.  Cue 80 minutes of derivative horror sci-fi.  It all slavishly follows every cliché first established so brilliantly by Alien(s) and resurrected in a 1000 straight-to-video titles. We have the cryogenics, the dark, industrial corridors, the gung-ho marines getting wiped out, the corporate guy betraying everyone to make his fortune. All very predictable, but oddly entertaining.  The special effects are surprisingly competent, Isaac's direction better than a special-effects-technician-got-lucky should be.  Lisa Ryder 'going a bit Lara' in black leather is excellent.  But the script is terrible and betrays all the faults of a woefully inept first timer.  Manfredini's music is VERY bad, and incorporates nothing of the classic moody effects he provided for the original.  Even the killings are tame, and have nothing of the splatter shock of the early eighties - blame 90's irony and the need to bring in the lucrative teen market for that one.A bad movie, make no mistake.  It's trash, but it pretends to be nothing more, and is oddly entertaining as a result.  Certainly not worth the price of a cinema ticket, but definitely a good video to rent after a few pints.

What a movie this is! Now right of the bat this isn't a good movie in the traditional sense. It's got mediocre acting all around and the writing is as schlocky as you can get, filled with puns, meta, and references. But it's not as obnoxious as it sounds.I actually really enjoyed this movie, more so than a few of the previous ones in the franchise. It's really silly, but in a good way in that it just doesn't care about trying to be serious anymore. This is the kind of refresh I needed after so many failed attempts to try and make the film serious again.So here the plot is basically moved to the future and instead of a camp its a spaceship jason is confined to. The teens/students on there are still the same characters and still as stupid as any other F13 film. The lead is not very memorable not smart either, as she's supposed to be an expert on Jason but never comes with any ideas.The way jason looked in this film was alright, he's definitely looked scaries, but his final form is great, not scary but definitely designed well. Now about Jason, the kills in this movie are pretty good with one of them added to ''most memorable kills'' in my opinion, which is the frozen face kill. It's also the best kill of this movie but overall the kills are good. Noticeably a lot of the actual 'killing'' gets censored but there's always some kind of aftermath that is used or shown in a interesting/fun way.Overall I felt this movie was paced pretty well, I didn't hang around too much and felt much easier to watch. The music is a bit iffy, the main theme comes back here and there but it's definitely not used as well here. The directing was alright, just about interesting enough but they really didn't care about building much suspense or making it seem like jason sneaked around, he kinda just appears everywhere full frame.There are some ridiculous scenes though like jason flying from the explosion in space and the Android doing some insane action moves. Like I said before this film definitely leans heavily into the comedy/crazy than the serious.For me its a 5/10, not terrible like Jason going to Manhattan, but also not even close to F13 part II because Jason just never became scary anymore, nor an attempt was ever made.

Well, if your going to watch this movie you probably are expecting the trash that it is. BUT this isn't TOO bad, their are many, many horror films, Friday the 13th films, and Jason knock-off films that are much worse. Don't get me wrong, Jason X is stupid. I really, really hate all of the characters with a passion, but I did appreciate the unnecessary nudity near the end.There are some good death scenes that continue the tradition that Friday the 13th helped create. This movie basically amounts to "Friday the 13th Part Ten: Jason in Space" and since EVERYTHING having to do with space is ALWAYS in the future, (its amazing how everything in outer space is in the future, isn't it? So does that mean the space shuttle time travels?)this is no exception and set in like the 69th century or whatever. Titantic sucks.

Review title: Not as bad as I expected and pretty good for a movie that is a 10th sequel
Review_body: Jason X I have to admit is a rare, good sequel. Usually movies that are up to the third or higher sequels tend to usually stink (ex. Halloween) and others that don't stink (ex. Evil Dead). The movie did something that I wish all movies that are not in the drama categories did: the actors/actresses did not try to act. The ones that did, at least succeded. Their are only a few times when they try and don't succed but it was rare. And to be honest, I thought the special effects were good. And at least the movie didn't have rock music blasting throughout the whole movie.8/10

After the previous nine movies, I wasn't sure what to expect from this one, but I have to say I was shocked at how good it was!  It's funny, has some very inventive death scenes, and above all never takes itself to seriously!!Money has obviously been spent on it, and the script has some great one-liners.  The acting may not be the greatest, but the actors give everything, and that helps.  At least in this slasher movie, you actually want some people to survive!A shockingly good movie!

Review title: Über Jason should have arrived earlier in this so-so slasher
Review_body: 'Jason X' manages to claw back a bit of dignity from the stench left by its turgid predecessor. Despite the outlandish premise of Jason being revived in space 400 years later, the idea holds promise. Unfortunately it can't capitalise on the claustrophobic possibilities of a serial killer stalking a spaceship's crew members one by one.Bland characters and a cheap, television movie look are prominent setbacks. This tenth entry, despite breaking free from its 1980s violence limitations, is also strangely tame in its kills, with the majority of them taking place offscreen, leaving the audience to view the grisly aftermath instead. No doubt a consequence of its low budget.But despite all the negative points in this science fiction horror, there's a late burst of creativity. Jason Voorhees is dispatched and everyone thinks the threat is over, but due to some futuristic nanotech reconstruction, he is reborn as Über Jason - an undead/cyborg hybrid that looks like something the Nazi's would have made via necromancy in some crazy alternate reality (think the video game Wolfenstein). Seeing this Terminator-styled monster become even more unstoppable adds some much needed energy in the final stretch, making this final film in the franchise a watchable, if lacklustre, instalment.5/10

*major spoiler!*It had to happen sooner or later. "Jason X," the tenth installment in the undying "Friday the 13th" series puts the masked killer in the 25th century. After being frozen for hundreds of years, he is revived aboard a interstellar craft, where he calmly picks up a machete and goes about his usual work. It sounds like a fan geek's dream, but that doesn't negate the fact that it's a pretty stupid movie. To be honest, it's also kind of dull up till the last act, more on that in a minute. Director James Isaac opens the film with a stylish credit sequence and sets up the story in a fairly interesting way, at least for a slasher. There is even a cameo by cult favorite David Cronenburg. However, as it goes on, it's clear that he has no real sense of pacing, nor does he often demonstrate the ability to scare us. To be fair, that would be hard to do with such flimsy material. It doesn't help that there are a couple of groan-inducing bits regarding severed body parts.The production values are just so-so, betraying its low-budget origins. I would have been much more forgiving in this area if treated to a good story, but it was not to be. The special effects are sometimes adequate, sometimes blatantly fake-looking. I wasn't expecting anything as good as Ridley Scott's "Alien," but at the very least, they should have tried to make it swift and entertaining. The sixth, seventh, and eighth entries were fun to watch in a cheesy sort of way. They were pretty silly, but certainly diverting. "Jason X" is just plain bad. However, at least the third act picks up a bit, as an android crewmember apparently finishes the killer off--until he is revived as a cyborg. Still stupid, but more watchable.Needless to say, the acting is mediocre at best, but what could these performers have done with such poor material? At least Kane Hodder, as Jason, seems to be enjoying himself. One cast member in particular is as awful as Carrot Top, but he is thankfully dispatched early on. Lexa Doig, as the heroine, has some appeal, but there wasn't much she could do here. Most of the other actors are ineffectual at best, annoying at worst. I guess most slasher movies will always suffer these faults to a degree. This one certainly doesn't miss an obligation: the door is left open for a sequel.*1/2 (out of ****)Released by New Line Cinema

JASON X is the tenth Jason Voorhees picture in his long-running Friday THE 13th franchise and it was released in April of 2001 and the film gets a lot of hatred. Paramount sold the franchise to New Line Cinema after JASON TAKES MANHATTAN and the film's concept is just really cool.Not only I'll review this, but like the remake of Jason, Halloween and Freddy Krueger, I will defend this movie. The story for this film is that Jason gets frozen and no one discovers him until 2455. By this time, Earth no longer exists and everyone lives on a planet called Earth II. Jason gets brought to life by a group of students / teachers that went to Earth to explore the land or something and he starts killing people on board the ship.A lot of critics and fans actually hated this one and says it is worse than "Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday", but actually, I don't mind this film at all because there are two Jason's, but they are played by the same guy.The acting is dreadful in a few areas, but I can easily overlook that. Kane Hodder plays Jason and he does good with his screen time, although this would be his final appearance as Jason and he is alright. This is all sci-fi with a mix of horror. Jason Goes to Hell was bad, but I find myself watching it once in a while. But, this one is not as stupid or pointless as the other films, like critics and fans did take those films the wrong way. I loved what New Line did to this franchise and to see Paramount getting the franchise back for the 2016 remake, yes, they are remaking it again and that is really cool. Or it might be a sequel to the 2009 reboot, I don't know.Parts 1-4 were really scary and intense, while 5-9 were also scary and much better than some of the pointless sequels in certain franchises and I can see why some of those get a lot of hatred.Overall, JASON X is kind of bad, but in a good kind of way and this film is a guilty pleasure for me. I love the direction, acting, music, visuals, action and horror scenes in this film and Kane Hodder could have not done a better job. I wish I could give this a a 10 out of 10, but considering the flaws that I have with this film, I can't. So I'm giving this a 6.3 / 10.

Review title: Ridiculous. Mostly in a fun way.
Review_body: If a horror franchise is allowed to drag out to the double digits then sooner or later the killer is going to space. It's just going to happen. I'm a little disappointed that the Jaws franchise hasn't made it that far yet, I'd have liked to have seen that.This time, it's Jason Voorhees, who gets cryogenically frozen in a cold open set in the present day. At this point the franchise had already established that the authorities recognized Jason as a real unkillable threat, not an urban legend, so it makes sense in-universe that certain unscrupulous people would want to study him to find out how he's avoiding a permanent death. Lexa Doig is great as Rowan, the scientist who determines that the safest way to deal with Jason is to freeze him. Unfortunately due to interference from an opportunistic colleague, she winds up being frozen along with Jason. These sequences are actually pretty decent and don't look too cheap. Fast forward four centuries though, and welcome to some production values that look like an Asylum flick on the Syfy channel. A team of improbably dressed explorers finds the cryochamber, defies all common sense in opening it, and then proceeds to behave in such a reckless manner that someone gets his arm hacked off. This turns out to be a group of teens on a space field trip, being led by an instructor (Jonathan Potts in fine smarmy form) who turns out to be more interested in making a few bucks on the side than in their educational welfare. They take both Rowan and Jason aboard their laboratory vessel and just as soon as two of the teens frolic off to get busy, the whole ship is in trouble. The rest of the film is Rowan, the students, crew and their space marine escort trying to first contain Jason, and failing that, escape from the ship as it falls apart. Kind of like one of the more recent Alien movies, except it's Jason and the special effects are sometimes hilariously special. There's a lot of live ammo being fired in confined spaces, which seems like a really bad idea in a space ship. Then there's an Aeon Flux inspired sequence, which the actress (Lisa Ryder) carries off with winky aplomb. Peter Mensah is also great as the redoubtable Sergeant Brodski. Overall, this is one of the weaker entries in the series, but it's got a lot of cheese appeal. It's definitely worth at least one watch.

One of the aspects of this film that contributed to its awful-ness was the large cast, many of which get only a moment of screen time, many of them look similar to others, and it is hard to keep track of who is who, until nearly everyone dies and you are left with a final few.The premise is rather silly too, while it was another attempt at taking Jason out of Crystal Lake, taking him to space, of all places, not to mention it being set years ahead in the future, was rather painful, to the viewer (as well as the characters in this film). I believe that the premise of the Friday the 13th films, set at Crystal Lake, is what makes the Friday the 13th films so cool.The cast are, like many other Friday films, all Jason-fodder, and while there are a varying degree of personalities, most get so little screen time they are utterly forgettable, with the notable exception of Lexa Doig, who gives a terrific performance.Overall, this movie is worth a watch, but unlike other Friday the 13th films, it's one that you may only want to watch once.

With a plot outline that reads: "Jason Voorhees returns with a new look, a new machete, and his same murderous attitude as he is awakened on a spaceship in the 25th century." Do you really expect this to be any good? I sure hope not. This is easily one of the worst, if not the worst sequel in "Friday the 13th" franchise history. Who thinks this stuff up, honestly? How could sending Jason into space ever seem like a good idea? Not to mention the mere fact it takes place after the events of "Freddy versus Jason" really takes the surprise out of whether or not Jason loses in that movie. Which is too bad too, because "Freddy versus Jason" looks like "Lawrence of Arabia" next to this piece of garbage.The most ridiculous part is when "evil gets an upgrade" as the tagline so ridiculously puts it. Come on, this isn't necessary. Just because a "Friday" film is set in the future doesn't mean Jason has to change with the times, in fact he should be the only constant. It shouldn't matter what generation Jason is in, he should be able to be just as dangerous and effective a killing machine regardless of what he's wearing.This movie is guilty of countless crimes against the cinema. How this project ever got the green light is a complete and total mystery to me. At least when I saw it, someone else rented it, so I didn't have to spend my own money on it. Overall, I'd say this is not worth the rental, and it's barely worth watching even on television for free! It is an insult to the intelligent horror film fan.

Jason X is the tenth installment of the overrun Friday the 13th horror series. As with any movie series with 10 parts, it cannot and must not be taken seriously. The story for Jason X is as ridiculous as they come. Mass murderer Jason Voorhees is cryogenically frozen for 500 years from now when he comes back to life on a spaceship heading for Earth 2. Aside from the stomach churning acting in the film there are a few scenes that are worth watching. If you rent this film on DVD just go to the Jump To A Death feature to watch the hilarious killings that take place. Aside from the cool new upgrade Jason gets (to become Uber-Jason), this film is totally unmemorable. I would not recommend watching this film all the way through, it is not worth anyone's time.

Jason X was a fine way to reintroduce the master of slaughter to the younger naive generation. But it backfired as the film ended up becoming a joke to most and a celebration to few. This could in part be because we were tantalized for years about the proposed Freddy vs Jason and by this point it was what we wanted. Another reason this failed at the box office is because it had been a decade since Jason last stalked his game, and the world had moved on, that's a sad thought. I myself love this movie and could watch it non-stop but then again I am biased as I love the character and the story, I could see if you were not a fan or if you were a fan and expecting more, that this would not be your cup of tea. But to those who only think of this film as joke, you are wrong. This film had lots of heart and took a heck of a long walk to get to screen, the battle that this film had to through to get shown should be made into a movie it was so wicked. Studio Execs leaving, people feeling Jason was not worthy to return, stupid people, and the internet were all causes for this film to be halted, but it prevailed and was shown and I think thirty million is not a bad number for a film that was not properly released or advertised. In the end this film came out swinging and was beautiful, it was the first Jason film I saw in the theater and I was elated. This is far better than Ronny Yu's soiled down Freddy vs Jason that would come a year later. or three years later if you count the fact that Jason X sit on a self at New Line for three years. I wonder how long it will take them to release the new Michael Bay produced remake once completed. My gut says it will go out quickly and be targeted at ignorant people and sell quick thus ruining the integrity that is and forever shall be Jason. See Jason X it well worth it and if you look at it, it is a fine conclusion to the chronicles of The Crystal Lake Slasher.

Subintelligent characters, idiotic conversations and behaviors, atrocious acting and CGI, boring soundtrack, a movie production seemingly made for TV in the 90s. I think I saw a 20th century rifle scope on their futuristic BFG in 25th century, just wow. Said to have a big budget, really? Truly pathetic, I just stopped watching cos this Jason sucks big freaking ass.

Taking the story into space has never worked out for any slasher movie franchise, but "Friday the 13th"
not only manages to get it right but to also once again deliver mindless fun with a bit of science fiction thrown in for good measure.

Review title: This sucks in so many levels
Review_body: Now all we need is bride of Jason and the stupid will be completeSeriously: slashers are stupid. This slasher series was always stupid (the first one was servicable) and never took any chances and I'm so sick of villains that don't die. At least the final chapter and a new beginning changed things up. This movie is worse than those. Yes I said it.

Jason X is one of the more entertaining Friday the 13th sequels, but that doesn't make it any less terrible or stupid. I do like how they just kind of gave up and made the characters say stupidly hilarious things, but it loses all those points from the abhorrent CGI, awful acting, idiotic characters, and an overall ridiculous plot. (Seriously though, they gave up big time. Like they didn't try at all). I'd complain about how the never explain how they didn't explain how they got Jason back from hell, but I don't really care at this point. If you need something in the background, then this is the perfect movie for you.

This movie knows it's bad. It doesn't pretend to be anything more than it being about Jason slicing and dicing in outer space. So does the movie get a pass? Is it a so bad it's good movie?There are definitely moments that are too silly even when you suspend your disbelief. As the plot moves forward the movie becomes more over-the-top and unbelievable.However I liked the attempt to create something new. The mix of a horror icon with Sci-Fi. There were a lot of funny and scary scenes. I liked how the movie doesn't take itself seriously and the characters have corny jokes and one liners. Some of the scenes with Jason were scary and I also liked the futuristic environment used for survival. It was an interesting dimension to a slasher movie.So even though it isn't the most memorable horror movie it was still entertaining.

Well, you don't watch a film in the "Friday the 13th" series expecting logic, sense, or high production values. But if you like slasher films (as I do!) you do expect a measure of gory fun.Jason X, unfortunately, provides that only up to a point. Though some of the killings shown are imaginative, others are so casually, even carelessly, presented, that you're left saying "Huh?" rather than screaming in terror (or laughter). My favorite in this respect: when the soldier Sven is yanked backward and has his neck broken, the two highly trained (LOL) soldiers with him don't even notice for several minutes. When they do, one asks "Where the hell's Sven?" - and that's that. No attempt is made to find/contact him or avenge his death. If the characters don't care, why should the audience?Special effects, which might have redeemed this, are poor and the movie otherwise has all the flaws of the genre  idiotic plot, characters who are any or all of stupid/greedy/venal, and a villain who is improbable  nay, impossible  to say the least. The music is so pallid that they might as well not have bothered with any.If you're a fan of the series, you might enjoy this. Otherwise, forget it.Rating: 2/10.

Review title: I guess this movie must've taken place on a Thursday
Review_body: The 9th film in the Friday The 13th series claimed to be "The Final Friday" so I guess this movie must take place on a Thursday. But it doesn't really matter what day it takes place on, nothing could save this mind-bogglingly bad movie. Jason. In space. You just can't help but wonder what the hell they were thinking. It reminds me of the show "Josie & the pussy cats in space." Some characters just shouldn't be set in space and Josie & the pussycats and Jason are prime examples of this.Man, what a bad movie.My rating: 1/10
This movie is very horrible. every actors and actress are so horrible

This is a film that proves that hollywood is only about money. Canyou imagine pitching this story? It's absolutely ridiculous! Anyonewho wastes time on this trash needs to get a life. 
                                                  Sincerely, Michael Myers

As a Friday the 13th Fan, this was the film I surprisingly watched the most of. It may not be good as everyone says it's not, but this is such a fun movie and I binge watch this one in particular to the rest for the creative kills and the fun scenes. Also, I love the idea the upgraded Jason Voorhees!

Review title: Not believable, not scary, not gross - not good!!
Review_body: First, let me say that I am a big fan of the "Friday the 13th" movies though they just have not been very good since Part 4 - like a stupid fool, I still rush to the movies when a new one comes out. The reason the first four Fridays were scary was because they actually attempted to take themselves seriously, they didn't try to be funny and they didn't use corny one-liners - comedy has no business in a horror film. This latest entry is one of the worst (although 8 & 9 were also very bad). There are so many, many movies about space - why did director James Isaac choose to make a Friday the 13th film if his real inspiration was the "Alien" movies. I actually found myself yawning throughout this film and did not find one single scene to be scary. It wasn't scary, it wasn't gross (one gross killing out of 30 is not enough) - it wasn't good. I hope if New Line decides to put out a new Friday film, they will put Jason back in the woods where he belongs and where he is scary, and give him back his old look of hockey mask and dirty farm clothing - the Uber-Jason at the end of the film looked much more like a comic book villain than a serial killer.

Review title: New Line Cinema is destroying Jason's character
Review_body: New Line's acquisition of the Jason Voorhees name, trademark, what-have-you have proved to be a big mistake in my opinion. Between Jason Goes to Hell and Jason X (both New Line products) these two movies are a horribly naive attempt to cash in on a new idea of what a Jason/ Friday the 13th movie should be like in the modern world of today. Jason Goes to Hell was the better of the two but this movie (Jason X) was just utterly horrible. The characters are still composed of the traditional sex-crazed teenagers, with some adult authority kicking around. The new 'space-craze' phenomenon sucked in the Jason/Friday the 13th series and for some reason the director (whose name escapes me right now) must have had a perverse look at what it would be like in the year 2455. This is Flash Gordon meets Jason Voorhees type material, really pathetic. There is no time for character development at all, they die off too quickly for starts. The guy with his own personal robot was a little too icky for me, the sex-crazed couple, the corrupted leader who has his own issues with bondage. There is simply way too much stuff going on that doesn't need to be going on, big time although 'cheesy' special f/x and horrible dialogue really make for the most of the movie. Jason's appearance is still grotesque as always, there is the nutcase (supposedly) that knows of the Jason legend (sounds like Crazy Ralph to me) and then the new invention of the regeneration of dead tissue? C'mon! Jason is the only reason for seeing this, you probably already knew that. Good luck sitting through it!

After Jason Takes Manhattan and Jason Goes To Hell my expectations dropped tremendously, and while this story is way out there, I think they handled this one pretty good. I wasn't really a fan of Jason's new look and I don't really get how he could've come back or "regenerated" if he went to hell but those are my only complaints. I also really liked that ending, the way everything came full circle was a pretty suitable conclusion.

Review title: A Damn Good Outer Space Time With That Ticked Off Goalie
Review_body: I saw this movie alone in the movie theater, and I'll tell you, I enjoyed the hell out of it. It is an honest to goodness horrible movie.  I am so glad that movies like this are still made.  This baby is a corker.  The actors are horrible, the teenagers are stupid, and Jason is in rare form, even though he has been frozen for like 2,000 years. They have really taken this franchise as far as it can go, but I hope that they take it further.  They should go every other, like one crazy sci fi Jason film followed by one set in the present day.  I wish it was the 80s, where you could count on Jason every year like taxes.  This is one of my favorites out of the series, simply because it is so damn hilarious and bad.

Review title: A smartly made, witty and inventive sequel
Review_body: A Friday the 13th movie set 400 years into the future which takes place in outer space, ludicrous right? Well you'd think so but this scenario actually works in Jason X, the tenth instalment of the Friday the 13th franchise and the second to be released by New Line Cinema after the debacle that was Jason Goes to Hell (1993) which promised to be the Final Friday, but of course it wasn't.Thanks to a witty script by Todd Farmer and smart direction by James Isaac this is an enjoyable sci-fi horror action movie and a welcome change to see Jason in a different setting. It delivers some inventive kills, is funny where it's supposed to be and is not as bad as some reviewers would have you believe. In fact I avoided watching this for almost 20 years as I thought the filmmakers had gone too far in a desperate attempt to keep the franchise going, I was pleasantly surprised to see just how good it was, even 20 years on.Produced by original Friday the 13th creator Sean S Cunningham with his son Noel Cunningham the gamble to put Jason Voorhees into space paid off, probably because this is for all intents and purposes Alien (1979), but instead of HR Giger's creature jumping out and killing the crew it's the unstoppable Jason who terrorises the spaceship. Played once again to good effect by Kane Hodder the serial killer gets a cool makeover when he's regenerated by nano technology after being cryogenically frozen since 2008 in an attempt to contain the killer.Jason X has the highest budget of all the Friday the 13th movies costing $11 million due largely to it's digital effects, where the average Friday movie would cost around $3 million. Not faring well at the box office upon it's release it's certainly worth a revisit and a reappraisal.Look out for an appearance by legendary horror film director David Cronenberg who, as Dr. Wimmer, holds Jason captive in the Crystal Lake Research Facility before he inevitably escapes.

Review title: Not the best, but not the worst
Review_body: Well its the long awaited Friday the 13th part 10.  When I was a kid I figured the series would have 13 installments and now that doesnt seem to out of reach. The series takes an unexpected turn and pits Jason a few centuries ahead of time aboard a space ship, and when his body thaws out all hell breaks loose.  So like all Jason movies, theres slicing and dicing.  But you think with the change of plot the deaths would all differ much. But instead their mostly by merchedi or offscreen.  Anyways, ** out of **** stars.

I expected from this film due to the budget, but obviously it was all just flushed. I'm a fan of Jason. I like Fridays 1-6 (parts 3-5 very much). Part 7 was "whatta hell is this TV-crap?" with a hilarious sleeping-bag execution, part 8 would have been OK if they wouldn't have been so shy with the gore and part 9 was just OK, with even some sight. I don't mind having a part 10 after "Jason goes to hell". I don't mind with the far-fetched plot here. I even don't mind tampering with Jason's outfit. What I DO mind here are these 2 things:-The actors seem to be reading their lines straight out of off-screen cards not even trying to act, which is uncomfortable and annoying. SHAME ON YOU!-The director DOESN'T EVEN TRY!!It all looks like bad cable stuff (even more worse than part 7!!) with NO kind of sense about lighting, cameras always at a distance from actor's faces (no close-ups), no creativity, no gimmicks... makes me wonder if there even WAS a director!? And the funny thing is, the "director" can't even blame the studio, 'cause he had a budget and obviously green light for gore and (even) nudity!Ain't nothing ever going to explain this mess. Talk about a CHEAT and WASTED POTENTIAL. Too bad for New Line, cause the studio had the courage...Avoid this turkey at all costs.

Review title: First Jason I saw in the theaters
Review_body: Ok, I've been a fan of past Jason films and always wondered how they could show cooler death scenes of stupid people. This movie does that. Only thing I wish is that when Jason is rebuilt they should of had a rocking fight scene and death scenes to the music from the trailer, Let the bodies hit the floor. That would of made it better.

I loved this movie.  In my opinion, this is the best of the JASON movies. Jason in space?  What a great concept!  This movie combined two of my favorite genres, horror and science fiction.  The movie delivers on all counts.  It has a great story line, and terrific special effects.  The movie is non-stop action and the killings are very creative.  This movie is very gorey, and in fact, I would say it is the most gorey installment of the FRIDAY THE 13th movies so far.  And without a doubt, this is the funniest movie of the series.  It has some really great laughs.  The director definitely seems to have a well developed sense of humor and a true love of action, horror, and sci fi.  This movie is awesome.  I loved the part when the space ship crashes in to the space station and then the space station explodes.  Also the part when the grunt gets cut in half and the next shot you see is the poor guy dragging half his body across the floor.
The characters are all likable and memorable.  Not to mention, this installment of the series definitely has the HOTTEST girls.  There are not too many other movies in general to come to my mind that have women of this calibre.In particular, I have to mention Melody Johnson.  She played the character "Kinsa."  I think she is absolutely gorgeous.  A modern day screamer-movie beauty.  She is incredibly sexy throughout the movie.  She kind of looks like Anna Paqin, but I think Melody is better looking.  She is just exactly my type.  I own JASON X on DVD and I put it in every once in a while just to check out Melody Johnson.  It seems unfortunate to me that Melody has not really done too many other movies.  She is so beautiful I would like to see more of her...A LOT more of her!If you are a fan of FRIDAY THE 13th, or just a sci fi or horror fan, you absolutely have to see JASON X.  The hologram sequence at the end where the "upgraded" Jason returns to Crystal Lake and encounters HOT co-eds is priceless.
